questions.text: A 67-year-old male presents to the emergency department with sudden painless vision loss in his left eye. He has had a similar episode before but his vision was quickly restored.  His fundus appears as shown below. Which of the following has no role in his management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the fundus picture showing a cherry-red spot is suggestive of central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO). Propranolol is a beta blocker used in the management of hypertension, but it has no known benefits in the management of CRAO.

Central Retinal Artery Occlusion (CRAO):

Emboli having carotid artery or cardiac origin are the most common cause of CRAO. The risk factors for CRAO include, Heart disease, Carotid artery disease, Mucormycosis, Varicella infection, Radiation exposure, trauma. Clinical features include, Sudden painless loss of vision, Amaurosis fugax(transient monocular blindness that is due to ischemia). Direct pupillary reflex is absent and RAPD is positive.

Fundus examination shows:

  • Marked attenuation of arteries – thread like arteries
  • Interrupted blood flow in vein – cattle track appearance
  • Cherry red spot
  • Severe edema 
  • Retinal pallor

Treatment is to dislodge the emboli by suddenly decreasing the IOP by I/V acetazolamide or ocular massage. Ocular massage is considered the most effective method. Other treatment options include IV mannitol, vasodilators (nitrates), fibrinolytic therapy, or laser photo disruption in some cases. In cases of giant cell arteritis, steroids are beneficial.

  • Retinotoxicity due to specific agents, including quinine, dapsone, gentamicin, carbon monoxide, and methanol

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the 6 x 6 x 6 strategy employed by the Anemia Mukt Bharat Program?
questions.solution:
Among the listed options, 6 testing methods are not a part of the 6x6x6 strategy employed by the Anemia Mukt Bharat Program.

The Anemia Mukt Bharat scheme is an initiative that aims to strengthen the existing mechanisms and foster newer strategies for tackling anemia. The 6 x 6 x 6 strategy represents:

  • 6 beneficiaries (option A)
  • 6 interventions (option C)
  • 6 institutional mechanisms (option D)

The 6 beneficiaries include:

  1. Preschool children (6-59 months of age)
  2. Children (5-9 years of age)
  3. Adolescents (10-19 years of age)
  4. Pregnant women
  5. Lactating mothers
  6. Young women in the reproductive age group (20-24 years of age)

The 6 interventions include:

  1. Prophylactic iron and folic acid supplementation
  2. Deworming
  3. Intensified year-round “behavior change communication campaign”
  4. Testing of anemia using digital methods and point-of-care treatment
  5. Mandatory provision of iron and folic acid-fortified foods in government-funded health programs
  6. Addressing non-nutritional causes of anemia in endemic pockets, with a special focus on malaria, hemoglobinopathies, and fluorosis

The 6 institutional mechanisms include: 

  1. Intra-ministerial coordination
  2. National Anemia Mukt Bharat unit
  3. National Center of Excellence and Advanced Research on Anemia Control
  4. Convergence with other ministries
  5. Strengthening supply chain and logistics
  6. Digital Anemia Mukt Bharat dashboard and online portal

questions.text: What is the use of the following instrument?

choices.text: To fix a chalazion during incision and drainage
To separate uveal tissue from sclera during evisceration
To engage the optic nerve during enucleation
To enlarge the bony opening during dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR)

questions.solution:
The given image is of a chalazion clamp. It is used to fix the chalazion and achieve hemostasis during the incision and drainage operation (Option A).

The chalazion clamp consists of two limbs like forceps, which can be clamped with the help of a screw. Excessive tightening of the screw can lead to pressure necrosis. The solid blade is placed externally on the skin and the ring-shaped blade is on the inner conjunctival surface.

Other options:

Option B: An evisceration spatula is used to separate the uveal tissue from the sclera during the evisceration operation. It consists of a small but stout rectangular blade with a slightly convex surface and blunt edges attached to a handle.

Option C: An enucleation spoon is used to engage the optic nerve in enucleation. It is identified by the central cleavage present to accommodate the optic nerve.

Option D - A bone punch is used to enlarge the bony opening during dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) operation by punching the bone from the margins of the opening. It consists of a stout spring handle and two blades attached at a right angle.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl was brought to her pediatrician with complaints of repeated hand-wringing movements and finger-licking.  On examination, microcephaly and marked regression of language milestones were noticed. What is the pattern of inheritance of this condition?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is Rett syndrome based on the stereotyped hand-wringing movements, repetitive behavior with regressed language milestones, and microcephaly. It has an X-linked dominant pattern of inheritance.

It is mainly caused by gene mutation of methyl-CpG-binding protein 2 (MECP2) and the condition is predominantly seen in girls. The onset is after a few months of apparently normal development.

Between the ages of 6 months to 2 years, affected children develop progressive encephalopathy. Other clinical features include stereotypic hand movements such as hand wringing, biting, or licking the fingers, and poor muscle coordination. Marked regression of all language skills and plateaued communicative and social skills can also be seen. Microcephaly develops as age progresses. Head circumference is normal at birth, but between the age of 6 months to 1 year, growth begins to decelerate. Seizures are an associated feature in a large number of cases. 

Supportive treatment is given. Physiotherapy is beneficial for muscular dysfunction. Anticonvulsants may be required to control seizures.

questions.text: The friend and victim had alcohol and got into an argument over a common girlfriend, following which the friend kills the victim by sitting on his chest and covering his nose and mouth. This is an example of?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is an example of burking.

Burking is a method of homicidal smothering and traumatic asphyxia where the assaulter kneels or sits on the chest (traumatic asphyxia) and close the nose and mouth with his hands (smothering). This was the method of killing performed by William Burke and William Hare.

Given image below shows burking:

Other options:

Option B: Smothering is a form of asphyxia that is caused by closing the external respiratory orifices either by the hand or by other means or blocking up the cavities of the nose and mouth by a foreign substance, such as mud, paper, cloth, etc.

 

Image given below shows smothering:

Option C: Traumatic asphyxia results from respiratory arrest due to mechanical fixation of the chest, by a heavy substance or object. The normal movements of the chest wall are prevented. There is a gross compression of the chest and usually abdomen by a powerful force, due to which chest expansion and diaphragmatic lowering are prevented. For example stampede deaths, crushing by falls of the earth in coal mines, or earthquakes.

Option D: Overlaying or compression suffocation results due to compression of the chest, so as to prevent breathing. It occurs when an intoxicated parent or other person shares a bed with an infant. The thoracic movements are limited and respiratory exchange is either reduced or completely prevented which leads to death. It is always accidental.

questions.text: An eight year old child presented with fullness in left ear. Otoscopy findings are shown in the image given below. Treatment of choice is _________

choices.text: Conservative treatment with antibiotics and analgesics

questions.solution:
The above case is suggestive of serous otitis media for which the treatment of choice is myringotomy with ventilation tube (Grommet).  

The image shows a golden yellow discoloration of the left tympanic membrane which is caused by the clear straw colored effusion filling the middle ear. Because the fluid is clear, one can see the structures of the inner ear quite clearly.

Treatment of choice for serous otitis media is myringotomy with ventilation tube (Grommet).

  • Grommet is a Tymapanostomy or ventilation tube placed in the middle ear to aerate and drain the middle ear into the external ear as a substitute to the blocked Eustachian tube.

Causes of otitis media:

Malfunctioning of eustachian tube:

  • Adenoid hyperplasia in children.
  • Benign and malignant tumours of nasopharynx (should be excluded in unilateral serous otitis media in an adult).

Other causes include:

  • Interference with ET opening like in cleft lip, cleft palate and enlarged tonsils
  • Otitic barotrauma
  • Increased middle ear secretions e.g allergy.
  • Persistent effusion of ASOM due to inadequate treatment dose or duration

Related Pearl: Myringotomy

Indications:
  • Acute suppurative otitis media:
    • Severe earache with the bulging tympanic membrane.
    • Incomplete resolution with opaque drum and persistent conductive deafness.
    • Complications of acute otitis media,e.g.facialparalysis, labyrinthitis or meningitis with the bulging tympanic membrane.
  • Serous otitis media.
  • Aero-otitis media (to drain fluid and “unlock” the eustachian tube).
  • Atelectatic ear (grommet is often inserted for long-term aeration).

Contraindication: Suspected intratympanic glomus tumor.

Incisions: 

  • In acute suppurative otitis media, a circumferential incision is made in the posteroinferior quadrant of the tympanic membrane, midway between the handle of malleus and tympanic annulus, avoiding injury to the incudostapedial joint.
  • In serous otitis media, a small radial incision is given in the anteroinferior quadrant and all the effusion is sucked out.

Complications:

  • Injury to incudostapedial joint or stapes.
  • Injury to jugular bulb with profuse bleeding, if jugular bulb is high and floor of the middle ear dehiscent.
  • Middle ear infection.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man exercises at a high altitude. Which of the following changes would occur in him?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, there will be a rise in urinary bicarbonate levels if a person is observed exercising at a high altitude.

Adaptation at High Altitudes:

  • The work capacity is reduced at high altitudes and this reduction is in direct proportion to the decrease in O2 uptake.
  • Immediate exposure to low PO2 at higher altitudes stimulates the arterial chemoreceptors, and this stimulation increases alveolar ventilation.
  • This immediate increase in pulmonary ventilation upon rising to a high altitude blows off large quantities of CO2, reducing the PCO2 and increasing the pH of the body fluids causing respiratory alkalosis (not metabolic - option A). This raised pH inhibits the brainstem respiratory center and opposes the increased ventilation. So, respiratory alkalosis will hinder maximal exercise effort.
  • To compensate for this respiratory alkalosis, kidneys reduce hydrogen ion secretion and increase bicarbonate excretion. This reduces plasma and cerebrospinal fluid bicarbonate concentration and brings the pH towards normal. It removes the inhibitory effect of alkalosis on respiration. Hence, fall in blood bicarbonate facilitates the exercise effort.
  • Lactic acid levels increase which causes extreme fatigue. When there is insufficient oxygen (at high altitudes), most of the pyruvic acid is converted into lactic acid, which diffuses out of the muscle cells into the interstitial fluid and blood.

questions.text: A patient complaints of vertigo, double vision and headache. She has fallen multiple times in the past few years and is unable to operate motor vehicles. Her symptoms have been dispersed in time and place with a relapsing pattern.  Ophthalmologic examination is given below. What is the most likely structure affected to cause these symptoms in eye?
questions.solution:
The symptoms and the examination findings point towards a diagnosis of internuclear ophthalmoplegia. The site of lesion in a case of internuclear ophthalmoplegia is medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF).

The command for left gaze originates from right cerebral cortex and runs to the left paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF). An output from the left PPRF runs to the left VI nerve nucleus supplying the left lateral rectus, causing abduction. An output from the left PPRF also goes to the right III nerve nucleus via the right MLF causing right eye adduction.

Therefore, a lesion in the right MLF leads to failure of the right eye adduction. The left eye, however, abducts normally. This is called internuclear ophthalmoplegia.

questions.text: The dip in blood pressure observed in the diagram below following phase 1 of the Valsalva manoeuvre is caused due to?

choices.text: Compression of the capillaries in the lungs
Increase in intrathoracic pressure adding to aortic pressure

questions.solution:
During the maintenance of the strain phase, there is reduced filling of the heart which is caused due to compression of the veins leading the a reduced venous return and stroke volume.

There are 4 phases in the Valsalva maneuver. 

Phase 1- There is a transient increase in the cardiac output due to an increase in the intrathoracic pressure.
Phase 2- The increased pressure compresses the veins resulting in decreased venous return and the stroke volume
Phase 3- There is a further reduction in left ventricular volume due to the expansion of the pulmonary vascular bed
Phase 4- Resumption of normal venous return to the heart stimulated by the sympathetic nervous system. 

Valsalva manoeuvre involves the performance of forced expiration against a closed glottis. It occurs during coughing, defecation, and heavy lifting. At the onset of straining, the blood pressure is raised because the increase in intrathoracic pressure is added to the pressure of the blood in the aorta. The pressure then falls as the high intrathoracic pressure compresses the veins and decreases the cardiac output. 

When the glottis is opened and intrathoracic pressure returns to its normal state, cardiac output is regained, but there is constriction in the peripheral vessels. As a result, blood pressure elevates beyond the normal range, which triggers the baroreceptors, leading to bradycardia and a subsequent decrease in pressure back to normal levels.

Other options:

Option A: Compression of the capillaries in the lungs leads to a slight increase in blood pressure as small amounts of blood later move into the heart.

Option C: An increase in intrathoracic pressure adding to aortic pressure would not reduce the blood pressure as the effect on the muscular aorta is far less than the veins due to lack of tunica media in the great veins thus making veins more susceptible to external pressure. 

Option D: There is a reduction in the ventricular volume and not an increase during the maintenance of the strain phase owing to increased intrathoracic pressure which causes compression of the heart and veins leading to reduced filling pressures.

questions.text: A 28-year-old sex worker presented with a painless ulcer on her vulva. On examination, inguinal lymphadenopathy is present. Which of the following methods has been used to demonstrate the causative agent as per the given image?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of syphilis caused by Treponema pallidum, demonstrated by dark-field microscopy. It is the the most specific and sensitive technique to visualize the organism when an active chancre or condyloma lata is present.

Dark-field microscopy images have a dark background with a refractile organism. The dark ground microscope has an optical system that enhances the contrast of unstained bodies.

The electron microscope, invented by Ernst Ruska is not commonly used for diagnostics in laboratories. It generally helps in appreciating viral structures. 

The fluorescent microscope uses fluorescent dyes like auramine-rhodamine to appreciate Mycobacterial species and malarial parasites.

questions.text:
A case of a high-speed motor vehicle accident with a GCS of E2M2V3 is admitted. On further evaluation, a normal CT brain scan with numerous microhemorrhages was seen on an MRI brain. For the given condition, all the following statements are true except.

GCS - Glasgow Coma Scale

choices.text: The most reliable indicator of axonal damage is beta-amyloid precursor protein
It is caused due to stretching of axons due to sudden deceleration injuries
Histopathology sections will reveal retraction balls on Reticulin stain
Several focal white-matter lesions are seen in this injury

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a patient with a poor GCS score, normal CT brain scan and numerous microhemorrhages seen on MRI following a road traffic accident is suggestive of diffuse axonal injury. It is associated with retraction balls which are seen on congo red staining. Meanwhile, the Reticulin stain is used to demonstrate the reticulin fibres.

Diffuse axonal injury is a form of primary brain injury seen in high-energy accidents. It is caused by damage to axons throughout the brain due to rotational acceleration followed by deceleration. There is disruption and shearing of axons leading to microhemorrhages.

Diffuse axonal injury typically consists of several focal white-matter lesions measuring 1-15 mm in a characteristic distribution. CT may be normal. Small haemorrhages can be seen in more severe cases, especially on MRI (investigation of choice). Hemorrhages are classically seen in the corpus callosum and the dorsolateral midbrain. 

The earliest microscopic evidence for diffuse axonal injury is 'retraction balls/globes' which appear 12-18 hours after injury. This can be appreciated using the Congo red stain.

Immunohistochemistry marker with beta-amyloid precursor protein is considered the most reliable indicator of axon damage. It is seen earliest at 2-3 hours.

The prognosis is poor. It results in a persistent vegetative state after severe head trauma.

The image shows scattered axonal retraction balls stained with Congo Red:

Retraction balls:

  • The force generated by violent shaking or rotational injury (as in a passenger ejected from the moving vehicle) can produce stretching of axons in cerebral white matter.
  • Microscopic examination does not show any axonal injuries up to 12 hrs after injury
  • After 12 hrs the axons first appear dilated then club shaped and finally appear as round balls known as retraction balls which indicates transected axons.
  • The number of retraction balls begins to decrease after 2-3 weeks after injury and cluster of microglial cells appear followed by astrocytosis and demyelination.

questions.text: A 2-year-old male child is brought with complaints of delayed developmental milestones and intellectual disability. On examination, the child had coarse facial features, hepatosplenomegaly, and a clear cornea. Which of the following recombinant enzymes is useful in treating this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child with intellectual disability, coarse facial features, hepatosplenomegaly, and a clear cornea is suggestive of Hunter's disease. Idursulfase a.k.a Elaprase is used in the treatment of this condition.

Hunter's disease is also known as mucopolysaccharidosis II (MPS II) resulting from the deficiency of iduronate sulfatase. This causes the accumulation of dermatan sulfate and heparan sulfate.

All MPS are inherited in an AR manner, except Hunter’s disease which is inherited in an X-linked recessive manner. The clinical features include coarse facies, gingival hyperplasia, macroglossia, short stature, dysostosis multiplex, macrocephaly, intellectual disability, and hepatosplenomegaly. Unlike other mucopolysaccharidosis, these patients lack clouding of the cornea.  

Elaprase a.k.a Idursulfase (Recombinant iduronate-2-sulfatase) is the treatment of choice for Hunter's disease to ameliorate nonneural manifestations.

Other options:

Option A: Aldurazyme a.k.a Laronidase in the treatment of Hurler's disease, also known as mucopolysaccharidosis type I. It is characterized by facial dysmorphism, hepatosplenomegaly, corneal clouding, upper airway obstruction, skeletal deformity, and cardiomyopathy. 

Option C: Galsulfase a.k.a Naglazyme is used in the treatment of Maroteaux–Lamy syndrome (mucopolysaccharidosis type VI). It is characterized by macrocephaly, hydrocephalus, macroglossia, short stature, marked corneal clouding, and contractures. 

Option D: Myozyme a.k.a Alglucosidase alfa, a recombinant form of alpha-1,4-glucosidase is used in the treatment of Pompe's disease. Clinical features include hypotonia (floppy baby syndrome), motor delay, cardiomegaly, macroglossia, hepatomegaly, failure to thrive, and poor feeding.

questions.text: A 69-year-old diabetic patient has come to you with excruciating right ear pain and right-sided facial palsy. An otoscopic examination of the ear shows granulations on the floor of the external auditory canal. Choose the correct statement regarding this condition.

choices.text: Technicium 99 is useful in monitoring disease
Antibiotic therapy is the treatment of choice

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of malignant otitis externa and antibiotic therapy is the treatment of choice.

Malignant otitis externa/ Necrotizing otitis externa is an inflammatory condition caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa in elderly diabetics and immunocompromised patients. It is characterised by excruciating ear pain, profuse discharge and granulations on the floor of the external ear canal. Necrosis of bone aids in the spread of infection. Infection may spread to the skull base and jugular foramen causing multiple cranial nerve palsies. Facial paralysis is the most common nerve palsy seen.

Gallium-67 scan is useful in the diagnosis and follow-up of the patient. It can be repeated every 3 weeks to monitor the disease and response to treatment. Technetium 99 bone scan reveals bone infection, but the test remains positive for a year or so and cannot be used to monitor the disease.

Treatment includes control of diabetes, toilet of the ear canal, removal of discharge, debris and granulations of dead tissue or bone.

Antibiotic treatment against P. aeruginosa for 6-8 weeks or more. If the patient is not responsive, treatment should be based on culture and sensitivity of ear discharge. Antibiotics that are usually effective against pseudomonas aeruginosa are gentamicin combined with ticarcillin (IV), third-generation cephalosporins (IV) e.g. ceftriaxone, ceftazidime along with an aminoglycoside, fluoroquinolones (ciprofloxacin, ofloxacin and levofloxacin) combined with rifampin (Oral).

questions.text:
You are studying the lung volumes of a patient with a spirometer. The patient is a known case of COPD. Which of the following will be increased in this patient?
  1. FRC
  2. TLC
  3. VC
  4. FEV1/FVC
questions.solution:
In COPD, the functional residual capacity increases. Total lung capacity may be increased or normal. Hence, both 1 and 2 are correct. In obstructive lung diseases:

  • Both FEV1 and FVC reduces, where the decrease in FEV1 is more than the reduction in FVC. As a result, the ratio of FEV1/FVC also decreases.
  • The total lung capacity is usually normal in chronic bronchitis, while increased in emphysema.
  • Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) is increased in COPD
     

Lung Capacities:

The total lung capacity can be broken down into alternative capacities that help to define functioning lungs.

  • The vital lung capacity refers to the maximum amount of air expired from the fully inflated lung or maximum inspiratory level.
  • The inspiratory capacity is the maximum amount of air inspired from the end-expiratory level.
  • The functional residual capacity represents the volume of the air remaining in the lungs after expiration of a normal breath. Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) is expiratory reserve volume + residual volume.

questions.text: Which of the following gland is infected in hordeolum externum?
questions.solution:
Hordeolum externum or stye is the staphylococcal infection of hair follicle/Zeis gland/Moll gland.

Hordeolum internum is an acute suppurative inflammation of the meibomian gland, associated with blockage of the duct.

The Chalazion is a chronic non-suppurative lipogranulomatous inflammation of the Meibomian gland.

The gland of Wolfring and gland of Krause are the accessory conjunctival glands.

questions.text: A 45-year-old obese lady with diabetes was managed with a thiazolidinedione group of oral hypoglycemic agents. Which of the following adverse effects is not associated with this group of drugs?
questions.solution:
Hypoglycemia as an adverse effect is not associated with thiazolidinediones group of oral hypoglycemic agents. 

The thiazolidinedione group of drugs (pioglitazone, rosiglitazone) activates PPAR-γ receptors in adipose tissue and skeletal muscles. These are insulin sensitizers and increase insulin-mediated glucose uptake in patients with type 2 diabetes. These also reduce hepatic glucose production and increase glucose uptake.

Thiazolidinediones (e.g., pioglitazone) can cause fluid retention, leading to oedema and heart failure exacerbation. Activated PPAR-γ receptors in the collecting ducts trigger increased ENaC-mediated sodium retention and upregulate vascular endothelial growth factor, creating a dual hit of plasma volume expansion and capillary leak.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman complains of fatigue, dry skin and cold intolerance since 2 weeks. She was started on amiodarone 1 month ago for persistent atrial fibrillation. Tests show high TSH (15 mU/l) and low free T4 levels. How would you manage this patient?
questions.solution:
Thyroxine supplementation is indicated for amiodarone induced hypothyroidism which is characterized by symptoms of hypothyroidism (fatigue, dry skin, cold intolerance) and lab findings (elevated TSH, reduced free T4) following amiodarone use.

Amiodarone induced hypothyroidism (AIH) can occur shortly after (as early as 2 weeks) amiodarone use due to iodine induced thyroid suppression (Wolff Chaikoff effect). It is characterized by clinical features of hypothyroidism and lab findings of elevated TSH and reduced free T4. It occurs more frequently in women and those with positive thyroid peroxidase antibodies. It is managed by thyroxine supplementation, without the need to discontinue amiodarone (Option A).

Amiodarone is an iodine-containing compound that is structurally related to thyroid hormone. It is a class III antiarrhythmic drug, which increases the duration of an action potential by blocking potassium channels, thereby increasing the time taken for repolarization. It is used to maintain normal sinus rhythm in atrial fibrillation.

Amiodarone can cause hypothyroidism due to the Wolff-Chaikoff effect, where excessive iodine leads to transient inhibition of organification and synthesis of thyroid hormones. Patients with underlying autoimmune thyroid disease are at increased risk of amiodarone induced hypothyroidism.

Other adverse effects of amiodarone include hypotension, bradycardia, myocardial depression, photosensitization, corneal microdeposits (corneal verticillata), pulmonary fibrosis, and peripheral neuropathy.

Other options: 

Option C: Corticosteroids would be indicated in amiodarone induced thyrotoxicosis and not amiodarone induced hypothyroidism.

Option D: Patients who are asymptomatic, with subclinical hypothyroidism following amiodarone use can be managed by observation and regular monitoring with thyroid function tests. Subclinical hypothyroidism is characterized by TSH level > 4.5 and ≤ 10 mU/l, normal FT4 and absence of clinical features of hypothyroidism.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the primary health center with a history of snakebite. The area of the bite is painful and appears red and swollen. From his description, the snake that bit him had a triangular head with a V-shaped mark as shown in the image below. All of the following statements regarding this snake bite are true except?

choices.text: Death is due to shock and haemorrhage
Persistent bleeding from bite site is noticed
Bleeding and clotting time are prolonged

questions.solution:
From the patient's description and the image, the snake is most likely Russell's viper. The victims of Russell's viper may become oliguric within a few hours of the bite suggesting renal ischemia.

The Russell's viper has a flat and triangular head with a V-shaped mark, white in color, with the angle of the V pointing forwards. Along the back, it has three rows of diamond-shaped spots. Other points of identification include broad plates on its belly, the small scales on the head, and a shield beneath the tail divided into two rows. It is commonly found throughout India.

Russell's viper venom contains two proteases that activate the blood-clotting cascade. Though more than half the victims have minimal or no poisoning, few develop serious generalized poisoning. At the spot where venom is injected, the patient develops severe pain and the area around the bite becomes red and painful. Persistent bleeding from the bite site is a constant feature. Blisters begin to appear in some hours which progressively involves the entire limb. Skin temperature is raised. Intravascular hemolysis may lead to hemoglobinuria which progresses to renal failure.

Since the venom affects the blood-clotting cascade, the bleeding and clotting time are usually prolonged. Patients may develop hemorrhagic syndrome due to bleeding from various sites like gums, rectum, etc. Death is usually due to hemorrhagic shock.

questions.text: What is the most common mutation seen in cystic fibrosis?
questions.solution:
The most common mutation in cystic fibrosis is Phe508del. 

Cystic fibrosis or mucoviscidosis is an autosomal recessive disorder with a mutation in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane regulator (CFTR) gene on chromosome 7q. The most common CFTR mutation is F508 deletion.

CFTR gene encodes for ATP-gated chloride channels in the apical membranes of epithelial cells. It regulates the flow of ions across epithelial membranes of sweat glands, respiratory airways, pancreatic ducts, etc. The defect leads to high salt concentrations in sweat and viscous luminal secretions in the respiratory and gastrointestinal tracts.

Clinical manifestations/ complications of cystic fibrosis include:
  • Sinusitis and nasal polyps
  • Respiratory - copious hyper-viscous and adherent pulmonary secretions with abnormal mucociliary clearance obstruct small and medium-sized airways leading to respiratory compromise. The disease can be further complicated by bronchiectasis and allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA).
  • Gastrointestinal - 
    • Thick and adherent exocrine secretions obstruct pancreatic ducts and impair the production and flow of digestive enzymes
    • Tissue destruction of the exocrine pancreas, with fibrotic scarring, cyst proliferation, and loss of acinar tissue - fat malabsorption, steatorrhea, fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies
    • Obstruction of intrahepatic bile ducts and parenchymal fibrosis leading to hepatic insufficiency and focal biliary cirrhosis
    • Distal intestinal obstructive syndrome in adults and meconium ileus in neonates
  • Reproductive - males have infertility due to the congenital absence of bilateral vas deferens and defective sperm transport, resulting in obstructive azoospermia. Females have infertility due to abnormalities of the reproductive tract secretions.

 The diagnosis is confirmed if both of the following criteria are met:

  • Presence of
    • Clinical symptoms affecting at least one organ system (respiratory, gastrointestinal, or genitourinary) or
    • Positive newborn screening or
    • A sibling with cystic fibrosis
  • Evidence of dysfunction of the CFTR gene by
    • Two positive sweat chloride test results were obtained on separate days or
    • Identification of two CFTR mutations by genetic testing or
    • An abnormal measurement of nasal potential difference

Cystic fibrosis requires a multidisciplinary approach to management. The correction of the defect can be via:

  • Lumacaftor, an FDA-approved drug that corrects the misfolding and reverts the Phe508del mutation defect
  • Ivacaftor potentiates CFTR channel opening and stimulates ion transport

End-stage pulmonary failure requires lung transplantation.

questions.text: Which of the following transport mechanisms is given below?
questions.solution:
The image showing sodium influx and calcium efflux is an example of secondary active counter transport.

Secondary active counter transport - In this form of transport, two or more substances are transported together across the membrane with the help of a carrier molecule. In counter-transport, sodium ions diffuse to the interior of the cell because of the large concentration gradient. Here, the sodium ions bind to the carrier protein on the exterior, and the substance to be counter-transported (calcium in this case) binds to the interior of the carrier protein. Once both are bound, a conformational change occurs, and energy released by the action of the sodium ion moving to the interior causes the other sub- stance to move to the exterior. The examples include:

  • Na+ Ca+ exchanger
  • Na+ H+ exchanger
  • H+ K+ exchanger

Other options:

Option A: Primary active transport - It is a form of cellular transport requiring energy in the form of hydrolysis of ATP to ship and transfer molecules against gradient differences. The important examples of primary active transport include sodium-potassium ATPase, proton pump, and calcium ATPase.

Option B: Secondary active co-transport: Here, the mechanism is similar, but both molecules are transported in the same direction (for example - towards the interior of the cell). One of the examples is SGLT (sodium-glucose co-transporter). Sodium-glucose cotransporter (SGLT)-1 transports molecules via secondary active transport where two or more molecules are transported together across the membrane with the help of a carrier molecule. As sodium diffuses down its electrochemical gradient, the energy released is used to drive glucose against the gradient. Other example include Na+ K+ 2Cl- co-transporter.

Option D: Facilitated diffusion - Transporting the molecule from one side of the cell membrane to the other is done with the help of transport proteins called carriers. Molecules move from areas of high concentration to areas of low concentration. No energy input is required when carrier proteins move substances in the direction of their gradients. Glucose(GLUT) transport by the glucose transporter is an example, which moves glucose down its concentration gradient from the ECF to the cytoplasm of the cell.

questions.text: Passive immunisation is not used in the prevention of disease caused by which of following viruses ?
questions.solution:
Passive immunization is not given in cytomegalovirus (CMV) exposure. At present, there is no role for post-exposure prophylaxis with antivirals or immune globulin. The only method of preventing maternal CMV infection is by limiting exposure to the virus by maintaining good hand hygiene.

Passive immunization is a short-term measure that is useful only when exposure to infection has just occurred or is likely to occur within the next few days. The duration of immunity is short and variable (1-6 weeks).

There are three types of preparations available for passive immunization -

  • Normal human immunoglobulin,
  • Specific (hyperimmune) human immunoglobulin
  • Antisera or anti-toxins.

Passive immunization has a limited value in the mass control of the disease. It is recommended for non-immune persons under special circumstances. Undesirable reactions may occur, especially with antisera of non-human origin. 

Passive immunization using immunoglobulins is done for the following diseases:

  • Hepatitis A
  • Hepatitis B
  • Hepatitis C
  • Rubella
  • Varicella-zoster
  • Measles (rubeola)
  • Rabies
  • Tetanus
  • Rh isoimmunization.

Passive immunization using antisera/ antitoxin is done for the following diseases:

  • Diphtheria
  • Tetanus
  • Gas gangrene
  • Rabies
  • Botulism

Other options:

Option A- Varicella-zoster immune globulin (VZIG) is used in immune-suppressed contacts of acute cases or newborn contacts for post-exposure prophylaxis.

Option B- Immune globulin (IG) is used in women exposed to the rubella virus during pregnancy.

Option D- The immune globulin for measles (rubeola) is used in infants less than 1 year old or immune-suppressed contacts of acute cases, exposed less than 6 days previously.

questions.text: A man presented with fever, cough, and chest pain for 2 weeks. Chest X-ray showed bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. Bronchoscopy revealed non-caseating granulomas. What is the gold standard investigation, if you suspect histoplasmosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Culture on Sabouraud's dextrose agar (SDA) is the gold standard for diagnosing histoplasmosis. This involves isolating and identifying the fungus Histoplasma capsulatum from a tissue sample (usually skin or lymph node) grown on SDA.

In SDA – white cottony mycelia growth can be seen.

Histoplasmosis caused by Histoplasma capsulatum is a thermally dimorphic fungus. The yeast form occurs mainly in tissues at a temperature of 37 °C and the mycelial form occurs in the soil at 25 °C. At room temperature, white, cottony, mycelial growth appears, with large (8-20 μ) thick-walled, spherical spores with tubercles (finger-like projections called tuberculate spores). Transmission is mainly via inhalation of microconidia. Treatment involves liposomal amphotericin B,  followed by itraconazole for at least 12 months.

Other options:

Option B: Chest X-ray can show findings suggestive of histoplasmosis, such as lung nodules, cavitations, or hilar adenopathy. However, these findings are not specific and can be seen in other lung diseases.

Option C: Serological tests can detect antibodies against Histoplasma capsulatum in the blood. However, these tests can be positive even in people who have had a past infection and are not currently sick. They can also be negative in people with early or disseminated histoplasmosis.

Option D: Urine antigen detection is a newer test that can detect Histoplasma antigen in the urine. This test is less invasive than tissue culture but is not as specific or sensitive.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with a rash on sun-exposed areas of the body and a history of ataxia and diarrhoea. His urine shows the presence of only neutral amino acids. A provisional diagnosis of Hartnup disorder was made. Which of the following tests will be positive in this condition?
questions.solution:
The Obermeyer test will be positive for Hartnup disorder.

The Obermeyer test detects the urinary excretion of indole compounds. Indole derivates such as indican are found in large amounts in patients due to bacterial breakdown of unabsorbed tryptophan in the intestines. 

Hartnup disorder is an autosomal recessive disorder due to a defect in the transporter for neutral amino acids like tryptophan. Decreased intestinal absorption of tryptophan in conjunction with its increased renal loss leads to its reduced bioavailability. This hampers niacin synthesis, and Hartnup disorder can thus present with manifestations of niacin deficiency (pellagra) like diarrhea, dermatitis, and dementia.

The major clinical manifestation is cutaneous photosensitivity. The skin becomes erythematous after sun exposure and might develop a pellagra-like rash and eczema over time. Some patients might have intermittent ataxia manifested as unsteady, wide-based gait. Cognitive development is usually normal, but there may be episodic psychiatric manifestations such as irritability, emotional instability, and depression. 

The diagnosis of Hartnup disorder is established by typical clinical history and the presence of neutral amino acids in the urine. Urinary excretion of other amino acids remains normal, which differentiates it from causes of generalized aminoaciduria like Fanconi syndrome. Treatment with nicotinamide and a high-protein diet gives a good response in symptomatic patients.

Other options:

Option B: Benedict's test detects the excretion of reducing substances in the urine. About 0.5 ml of urine is boiled with 5 ml of Benedict's reagent for 2 minutes. The formation of a precipitate is observed on cooling. The test is semi-quantitative and the color of the precipitate roughly parallels the concentration of reducing sugar.

Option C: Guthrie bacterial inhibition test is a screening test for phenylketonuria. This test uses a phenylalanine requiring strain of Bacillus subtilis.

Option D: Seliwanoff's test will distinguish glucose and fructose. The reagent is resorcinol in HCl. 3 ml of the reagent and 0.5 ml of urine are heated for 30 seconds up to a boiling point. A red color indicates the presence of fructose.

questions.text: Which of the following features of the genetic code is not applicable to mitochondria?
questions.solution:
The mitochondrial genetic code is not universal. 

The universality of the genetic code means that every codon is read the same in all organisms from viruses and bacteria to humans. For example, the codon-CUA is read as Leucine, whether it is a prokaryote like bacteria or a bird or human, the codon CUA will always be read as Leucine. Mitochondrial genetic code is exceptional in this feature of Universality. Example- In mammalian mitochondria, the codon AUA is read as Methionine which is universally read as Isoleucine.

Codon Universally(in the cytoplasm) read as: Mitochondria reads as:
AUG Methionine -
AUA Isoleucine Methionine
UGA Stop Tryptophan
AGG and AGA Arginine Stop

 

Mitochondria follows all the other features of the genetic code.

Non-overlapping (Option A): The reading of the genetic code during the process of protein synthesis does not involve any overlap of codons. It is read from a fixed starting point as a continuous sequence of bases.

Non-punctuated (Option B): The genetic code is non-punctuated. This means that once the reading commences at a specific start codon, it is continuous and is read continuously as triplets until a stop codon is reached without stopping.

Unambiguous(Option C): The genetic code is unambiguous because each codon is specific for only one amino acid. Example: GGA only codes for Glycine.

questions.text: Calcium binds to which of the following proteins during smooth muscle contraction?
questions.solution:
Calcium binds to calmodulin during smooth muscle contraction.

Increased cytoplasmic Ca2+ binds to and activates calcium-binding proteins (calmodulin, troponin) or activates protein kinases (or phospholipase C) to bring about physiological effects.

Calmodulin is structurally and functionally related to troponin. In place of troponin, smooth muscle cells contain a large amount of the regulatory protein calmodulin; it is different in the manner in which it initiates contraction. Calmodulin initiates contraction by activating the myosin light chain kinase. Troponin, on the other hand, initiates contraction by causing a conformational change in the tropomyosin molecule which then uncovers the active sites on the actin filament.

The sequence of events in smooth muscle contraction:

  • Binding of acetylcholine to muscarinic receptors
  • Increased influx of Ca2+ into the cell
  • Activation of calmodulin-dependent myosin light chain kinase
  • Myosin phosphorylation
  • Increased myosin ATPase activity and binding of myosin to actin

Actin, myosin, and tropomyosin are present in both skeletal muscle and smooth muscle.

Other options :

Option B: Actin is a protein that makes up microfilaments. Microfilaments are present in the outer zone of the cytoplasm and provide support to the cell membrane. In muscle cells, a specialized arrangement of actin provides the mechanism for muscle contraction.

Option C: Myosin is the major contractile protein found in muscle cells. Its specialized arrangement with actin is essential for muscle contraction. It does not play a role in axonal transport. 

Option D: Troponin molecules are small globular units located at intervals along with the tropomyosin molecules. Each of the three troponin subunits has a unique function:

  • Troponin T binds the troponin components to tropomyosin.
  • Troponin I inhibits the interaction of myosin with actin.
  • Troponin C contains the binding sites for the Ca 2+ that help to initiate contraction.

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of congestive heart failure is brought to casualty with complaints of sudden onset dyspnea. Bilateral fine basal crackles can be heard on auscultation. A bolus dose of injection furosemide was given.  Which of the following principles apply to the use of loop diuretics in this patient?
questions.solution:
Furosemide (which was given to the patient) acts on the principle of reduction of preload.

It comes under a class of drugs known as loop diuretics (high ceiling diuretics) and they are the diuretic of choice for reducing edema in heart failure. They act by inhibiting the Na+/K+/2Cl- symporter in the ascending limb of the loop of Henle.

This leads to a decrease in preload by increasing sodium and water excretion and improves ventricular function by reducing the circulatory volume. Intravenous furosemide also increases systemic venous capacitance.

The history of a patient who is known to have congestive heart failure being brought with complaints of sudden onset dyspnoea and bilateral fine basal crackles is suggestive of pulmonary edema. Heart failure is the inability of the heart to pump an adequate cardiac output for meeting physiological demands and can occur due to systolic/diastolic dysfunction. There is an elevation of filling pressure to compensate for the reduced cardiac output, but such an increase in stroke volume can produce congestive features similar to the scenario mentioned above. The main goal of drug therapy would be to relieve the congestive symptoms and restore cardiac function.

Other options:

Option B: In heart failure, low cardiac output causes activation of the neurohumoral regulation (renin-angiotensin-aldosterone-system and sympathetic nervous system) that leads to an increase in sodium and water reabsorption as well as elevation of blood pressure (causing an increase in afterload). Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors, angiotensin receptor blockers, and mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists act by the principle of reducing neurohumoral modulation.

Option C: Hydralazine act on the principle of reducing afterload by dilating resistance vessels. Reduction of afterload is beneficial in heart failure as it allows the heart to pump out blood against a lower resistance. 

Option D: Positive inotropic agents such as cardiac glycosides (Na+/K+ATPase inhibition - digoxin) and cAMP-dependant drugs (epinephrine, norepinephrine, and dobutamine) act on the principle of increasing cardiac contractility. This is beneficial as it allows to produce enough force for adequate organ perfusion.

Laser-assisted in situ keratomileusis or LASIK with the excimer laser is the most popular and widely accepted treatment modality among all the choices available at present. Excimer laser beam reshapes the cornea by ablating the superficial stroma to a predetermined extent after lifting a flap of the cornea with a sharp microkeratome. 

Patient selection criteria:

  • Ideally in individuals aged 21 years and above.
  • In individuals who have a stable refractive error for at least 1 year.
  • In individuals who have had unsatisfactory results with non-surgical treatment.
  • In individuals in whom corneal-thinning disorders such as keratoconus have been ruled out. (A normal corneal thickness is around 540-550 microns. Incidence of corneal ectasia increases with a thin cornea and therefore a corneal thickness of <450 microns is not a criteria for LASIK eligibility) 

Complications:

  • Tear instability (dry eye)
  • Wrinkling, distortion, or dislocation of the flap
  • Subepithelial haze with resultant glare, especially at night.
  • Persistent epithelial defects.
  • Epithelial ingrowth under the flap.
  • Diffuse lamellar keratitis (sands of the Sahara)
  • Corneal ectasia
  • Keratoconus

questions.text: What is the mechanism of late dumping syndrome?
questions.solution:
Late dumping syndrome occurs when a large quantity of food consumed leads to rapid hyperglycemia and a reactive insulin secretion occurs leading to hypoglycemia. This in turn leads to an increased production of catecholamines leading to her current symptoms. 

Dumping Syndrome can be early or late.

Early dumping syndrome:

  • It is due to the high osmotic load that reaches the small bowel, leading to sequestration of fluid from the circulation into the gastrointestinal tract (GIT).
  • This shift induces autonomic responses. It is charecterised by more GI and fewer cardiovascular effects. 
  • It is secondary to the release of several humoral agents, such as serotonin, bradykinin-like substances, neurotensin, and entero-glucagon.
  • Symptoms are aggravated on having more food and relieved on lying down.
  • Principal treatment is dietary manipulation. Meals based on fat and protein are known to work the best.
  • Following operation, the syndrome tends to improve with time.
  • Octreotide before meals are useful.
  • Revisional surgery may be occasionally required

Late dumping syndrome:

  • This syndrome is an effect of reactive hypoglycaemia
  • It is due to the high carbohydrate load in the small intestine, which causes an increase in insulin levels and secondary hypoglycemia.
  • This hypoglycemia activates the adrenal gland to release catecholamines, which results in diaphoresis, tremulousness, light-headedness, tachycardia, and confusion.
  • The symptoms are aggravated by exercise and relieved by having food.
  • Treatment is essentially the same as for early dumping
  • Octreotide is very effective in dealing with this problem

questions.text: Identify the correct classic adenoma-carcinoma sequence from the following.
questions.solution:
APC - KRAS - p53 is the correct classic adenoma-carcinoma sequence which is the pathophysiology behind adenocarcinoma colon.

Adenocarcinoma of the colon is the most common malignancy of the GI tract. The pathogenesis of colon cancer can be explained by three distinct pathways of genomic instability:

  1. Chromosomal instability/APC-β-catenin pathway/Classic adenoma-carcinoma sequence
  2. Microsatellite instability pathway (MSI)
  3. CpG island methylator phenotype pathway.

Chromosomal instability/APC-β-catenin pathway/classic adenoma-carcinoma sequence is the most common pathway, accounting for 80% of sporadic cancers. The "first-hit" in this pathway is the inherited or acquired mutation of the cancer suppressor gene APC on chromosome 5q21. Both copies of the APC gene must be inactivated. The "second hit" is due to methylation abnormalities and inactivation of the normal β-catenin. The loss of the second APC allele follows the "second hit." Mutations of KRAS on chromosome 12p12, TP53 on chromosome 17p13, and LOH at chromosome 18q21 are also involved in further steps of the classic adenoma-carcinoma sequence.
 
Microsatellite instability pathway (MSI) occurs in patients with DNA mismatch repair deficiency, leading to the accumulation of mutations in microsatellite repeats. The main pathogenic mechanisms are mutations of type II TGF-β receptor leading to uncontrolled cell growth, and loss of pro-apoptotic BAX which may enhance the survival of genetically abnormal clones.
 
CpG island hypermethylation phenotype (CIMP) - In these tumours, the MLH1 promoter region is typically hypermethylated, thus reducing MLH1 expression and repair function. Activating mutations in the oncogene BRAF are common in these cancers. KRAS and TP53 are not typically mutated. The combination of MSI, BRAF mutation, and methylation of specific targets, such as MLH1, is the signature of this pathway of carcinogenesis.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman with gout complains of acute onset redness of the eye as given below which is not associated with pain. On further probing, she gives a history of multiple visits to the hospital with the same complaints. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an elderly female with gout presenting with recurrent acute onset redness of the eye not associated with pain and the image showing a nodule away from the limbus surrounded by redness is suggestive of episcleritis.

Episcleritis is benign, recurrent, inflammation of the episclera, involving the overlying Tenon's capsule but not the underlying sclera. It is more common in women than in men. Causes include a hypersensitivity response to internal streptococcal or tubercular toxins. Syphilis, Tuberculosis, Lyme disease, and the herpes zoster virus can all lead to infectious episcleritis. It is also associated with systemic diseases like gout, rosacea, psoriasis and connective tissue diseases.

Episcleritis is characterized by redness, and mild ocular discomfort described as a gritty, burning, or foreign body sensation.

Clinically, two types of presentations may occur:

  • Simple episcleritis is characterized by sectorial or diffuse inflammation of the episclera. The image given below shows diffuse episcleritis:
  • Nodular episcleritis is characterized by a pink or purple flat nodule surrounded by erythema, usually situated 2-3 mm away from the limbus. The nodule is firm, and tender and can be moved separately from the sclera, and the overlying conjunctiva also moves freely.

Treatment includes topical NSAIDs, corticosteroid eye drops, cold compress, and artificial tears. In recurrent cases, systemic NSAIDs are used.

Other options:

Option A: Conjunctivitis is a refers to the inflammation of the conjunctival tissue, engorgement of the blood vessels, pain, and ocular discharge, and is classified as acute or chronic and infectious or noninfectious. Clinically it is associated with pain and discharge from eyes and other features based on etiology

Option B: Tenon's cyst or conjunctival inclusion cyst is a benign condition filled with serous fluid and slimy mucous secretions of congenital or acquired origin. The patient presents with swelling near the limbus with no pain or redness. The consistency is cystic to firm, non-tender with no mobility suggesting that the cyst is adherent to the underlying scleral tissue. The image of Tenon's cyst is given below:

Option D: Scleritis refers to an inflammation of the sclera proper. It usually occurs in elderly patients (40-70 years) involving females more than males. It is frequently associated with an underlying systemic inflammatory condition. The patient presents with moderate to severe pain, redness, lacrimation, photophobia, and diminution of vision.

questions.text:
A patient with CSOM presented to the OPD with seizures, headache, vomiting and photophobia. On eye examination, homonymous hemianopia was noted. CT brain showed the following findings. Identify the condition.

Chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM)
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette depicting features of seizures, headache, vomiting, and photophobia in a patient with a chronic ear infection and the CT image showing a ring-enhancing lesion point to a diagnosis of a temporal lobe abscess.

Temporal lobe abscess is an intracranial complication that can arise from chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM).

Brain abscess typically progresses through 4 stages.

  • The first stage is the stage of invasion (initial encephalitis), which often goes unnoticed. Symptoms such as headache, malaise, low-grade fever, and drowsiness may be present.
  • The second stage is the stage of localization (latent abscess), during which a capsule forms around the abscess, effectively localizing the pus.
  • The third stage is the stage of enlargement (manifest abscess). The abscess enlarges, leading to increased intracranial pressure (ICP) and the development of edema surrounding the abscess. As a result, symptoms worsen.
  • The final stage is the stage of termination (rupture of abscess). At this point, the abscess expands and eventually ruptures into the ventricle or subarachnoid space, which can result in potentially fatal meningitis.

Characteristic findings associated with temporal lobe abscess include nominal aphasia, homonymous hemianopia, seizures, contralateral motor paralysis, pupillary changes, and oculomotor palsy. Signs of raised ICP like headache, nausea, vomiting, lethargy, drowsiness, confusion, papilledema, and coma may also be seen.

The preferred diagnostic imaging modality for temporal lobe abscess is a CT scan of the brain. This imaging study reveals a ring-enhancing lesion indicative of a brain abscess.

Medical treatment involves initiating intravenous antibiotics, typically metronidazole. Raised ICP can be addressed using dexamethasone or mannitol. Surgical intervention is the definitive management and involves drainage of the abscess followed by radical mastoidectomy to address the underlying CSOM.

Other options:

Option B: Cerebellar abscess is a form of brain abscess and is usually associated with an otogenic source of infection. It can occur as a direct extension through Trautmann's triangle or via retrograde thrombophlebitis. 

An MRI image showing cerebellar abscess is given below:

Option C: Subdural abscess refers to the focal collection of purulent material between the dura mater and the arachnoid mater. 

An MRI image showing subdural abscess is given below:

Option D: Meningitis is the inflammation of the leptomeninges which includes the arachnoid mater and pia mater. It can be due to an infectious or noninfectious etiology. It presents with fever, vomiting, neck stiffness, and signs of meningeal irritation. Ring-enhancing lesion on neuroimaging is not a feature of meningitis.

questions.text:
In response to an increase in the GFR, the area marked 4 demonstrates an increase in the rate of Na+ reabsorption. This phenomenon is called _____________.

GFR- Glomerular filtration rate
questions.solution:
In the given image, the area marked 4 is the cells of the proximal convoluted tubule which are involved in sustaining glomerulotubular balance, a mechanism by which the percentage of the reabsorbed solutes is maintained at constant levels.
 
This is achieved by increasing the reabsorption of the solutes and water in the proximal convoluted tubule in response to increased GFR.

For example, if the GFR increases from 125 to 150 ml/min, the absolute rate of proximal tubular reabsorption also increases from about 81 ml/min (65% of GFR) to approximately 97.5 ml/min (65% of GFR). Therefore, even when the total rate of reabsorption and filtered load rise, the proportion of GFR reabsorbed in the proximal tubule stays relatively constant, at around 65%.

The given illustration shows:

1- Macula densa: These are specialized cells at the start of the distal convoluted tubule form the macula densa. 

2- Granular cells/JG cells: These are modified smooth muscle cells of the afferent arteriole; these are mechanoreceptors that secrete renin in response to a fall in blood pressure, which in turn, increases the blood pressure. 

3- Lacis cells: These are extraglomerular mesangial cells situated between afferent and efferent arteriole. 

Other options: 

Option A: Renal splay is the deviation in the actual renal threshold from the calculated renal threshold. If all the tubules in the nephron worked at a given time, then the renal threshold would be 300mg/dL, that is, 375 mg/min (TmG-transport maximum) divided by 125 mL/min (GFR). However, the actual renal threshold is 200mg/dL. This is because, at a given time, not all tubules are reabsorbing the glucose. 

Option B: Renal autoregulation maintains the renal blood flow to almost a constant level irrespective of arterial perfusion pressure within physiological limits. It is due to the action of vascular smooth muscles in renal afferent arteriole, which respond to stretch caused by blood pressure. This relative constancy of GFR and renal blood flow is referred to as autoregulation. 

Option C: Tubuloglomerular feedback (TGF) changes the rate of filtration and tubular flow by reflex vasoconstriction or dilatation of the afferent arteriole. It is mediated by specialized cells in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle called the macula densa that act as sensors of solute concentration and tubular flow rate.

questions.text: A patient developed a thyroid storm following radioiodine treatment. During the management, he is being given 5 drops of potassium iodide every 6 hours. This inhibits thyroid hormone synthesis by:
questions.solution:
Potassium iodide inhibits thyroid hormone synthesis by Wolff- Chaikoff effect. Large doses of iodide inhibit organic binding of the iodide and hence decrease thyroid hormone synthesis.

Other options:

Option A- Jod-Basedow phenomenon is the increased synthesis of thyroid hormone following exposure to iodine.

Option C- Second wind phenomenon is seen in patients with McArdle disease. After a short break from strenuous exercise, the patients can continue exercise without pain

Option D- Thyrotoxicosis factitia is the ingestion of excess thyroid hormone leading to thyrotoxicosis.

Mid tracheostomy, done through the 3rd  tracheal ring
High tracheostomy, done through the 2nd tracheal ring
High tracheostomy, done through the 1st tracheal ring

questions.solution:
Laryngeal carcinoma is an indication of high tracheostomy. It is done at the level of the 1st tracheal ring and an opening is made above the isthmus of the thyroid gland 

Tracheostomy involves making an opening and placing a stoma in the anterior wall of the trachea. 

High tracheostomy is done above the level of thyroid isthmus (Isthmus lies against II, III, and IV tracheal ring). The only indication for high tracheostomy is carcinoma of the larynx.

Functions: 

  • Provides an alternative pathway for breathing by bypassing the obstruction.
  • Improves alveolar ventilation by reducing dead space by 30-50% and reducing airway resistance
  • Uses a cuff to protect the airways from secretions and blood

Indications: 

  1. Respiratory obstruction due to 
    1. Infections (laryngo-tracheo-bronchitis, epiglottitis, diphtheria)
    2. Trauma due to external injury, mandibular or maxillofacial fractures
    3. Neoplasms
    4. Foreign bodies or edema
  2. Retained secretions
    1. Inability to cough due to coma, spasm, or paralysis of respiratory muscles
    2. Aspiration of pharyngeal secretions
    3. Painful cough
  3. Respiratory insufficiency due to emphysema, chronic bronchitis

questions.text: Which of the following is likely to increase in a patient who is brought to the casualty with acute diarrhoea?
questions.solution:
A patient with diarrhoea has an increase in hematocrit as a relative change.

Dehydrating conditions such as diarrhoea, burns and vomiting, cause loss of fluid from the extracellular compartment. There is no loss from the intracellular compartment and no change in the osmolarity. ECF volume contraction therefore is reflected by a relative increase in hematocrit.

The reverse is what occurs as a physiological change in pregnancy, where ECF volume expansion is reflected as physiological anemia of pregnancy.

Diarrhoea is usually managed by volume replacement with IV fluids. Administration of normal saline, ie, isotonic fluid would similarly lead only to ECF volume expansion with no change in the ICF volume or the osmolarity.

Whenever hypertonic saline is added to the extracellular fluid (ECF), the extracellular osmolarity increases. It causes osmosis of water out of the cells into the extracellular compartment. Almost all the added sodium chloride remains in the extracellular compartment and fluid diffuses into the extracellular space to achieve osmotic equilibrium. The net effect is that the volume of ECF increases, the volume of intracellular fluid (ICF) decreases, and the osmolarity of both compartments increase. 

Whenever hypotonic saline is added to ECF, the osmolarity of ECF decreases. This leads to the movement of water from the ECF to the ICF until both attain the same osmolarity. Both the intracellular and extracellular volumes are increased by the addition of hypotonic fluid, but the intracellular volume increases to a greater extent. Osmolarity decreases in both the compartments.

questions.text: All of the following methods of removal of hardness of water cause the precipitation of calcium carbonate except?
questions.solution:
Boiling and the addition of soda ash/ lime remove the hardness of water by the precipitation of calcium carbonate. The base exchange process leads to the precipitation of calcium and magnesium permutit.

Option A: Permutit is a complex chemical compound of sodium, aluminum, and silica that is used in the process of base exchange to remove the temporary and permanent hardness of water. It works on the principle of ion exchange to remove calcium and magnesium from water.

Option B: The addition of soda ash or sodium carbonate can remove temporary as well as permanent hardness and causes the precipitation of calcium carbonate. 

Option C: In Clark's method, lime or calcium hydroxide is added to water also to remove temporary hardness. The lime absorbs the carbon dioxide and causes precipitation of calcium carbonate.

Option D: Boiling the water can remove temporary hardness by precipitating calcium carbonate and expelling carbon dioxide. 

Related Pearl: Hardness of Water

  • Hardness is the soap destroying power of water or the amount of dissolved calcium and magnesium in water.
  • It is most commonly caused by bicarbonates and sulphates of calcium and magnesium but their nitrates and chlorides also cause hardness.
  • Carbonate hardness is also called temporary hardness and is caused due to bicarbonates of calcium and magnesium.
  • Non-carbonate hardness is called permanent hardness is due to sulphates, chlorides and nitrates.
  • Hardness is expressed in terms of milli-equivalents per litre (mEq/l).
  • One mEq/l of an ion that produces hardness is equal to 50 mg CaCO3 (50 ppm) in one litre of water.
Classification Level of hardness (mEq/l) Amount of ion producing hardness (mg/l)
Soft water Less than 1 Less than 50
Moderately hard 1 – 3 50 – 150
Hard water 3 – 6 150 – 300
Very hard water Over 6 More than 300
  • Drinking water must be moderately hard
  • Softening of water is recommended when the hardness exceeds 3 mEq/l (150 mg/litre)
  • Too much hardness in water asserts a undesirable effect on clothes, food, pipes, boilers, etc
  • Removal of hardness:
    • Boiling: This removes temporary hardness by expelling carbon dioxide and precipitating insoluble calcium carbonate. It would be expensive to do this on a large scale.
    • Ca(HCO3)2 → CaCO3 + H2O + CO2
    • Addition of lime: 
    • This removes temporary hardness and also reduces magnesium. Lime absorbs carbon dioxide and precipitates insoluble calcium carbonate. In Clark’s method of softening water, lime is used.
    • Ca(OH)2 + Ca(HCO3)2 →2 CaCO3 + 2 H2O
    • Addition of sodium carbonate (soda ash) removes both temporary and permanent hardness.
    • Base exchange process:
    • This removes permanent and temporary hardness and can be used in a large scale. In this method, permutit is used. Sodium permutit is a complex compound of sodium, aluminium and silica (Na2 Al2 Si2O H2O). When hard water is passed through this permutit, the calcium and magnesium ions are removed by base exchange and it is converted into calcium and magnesium permutit. This process reduces water to zero hardness, which is corrosive and thus it is then mixed with a part of raw water.

questions.text: According to the Warning Notice published by the Medical Council of India, a registered medical practitioner has been found guilty under the provision of advertising. Which of the following instances may not amount to professional misconduct under this provision?

choices.text: Putting up a signboard at a pharmacy where he doesn't work
Notifying the media twice that he is resuming his practice
Giving interviews about illnesses in an attempt to promote oneself
Indirectly promoting oneself through manufacturing firms

questions.solution:
A registered medical practitioner who intends to resume his practice is only permitted to notify the media twice. If he repeats it more than two times, he will face charges of professional misconduct.

The Medical Council of India and other State Medical Councils have published a Code of Medical Ethics, which specifies certain rules of conduct that a registered medical practitioner must adhere to.

Any person found guilty of any of the acts of commission or omissions listed in the Medical Council of India's Warning Notice will be considered to have engaged in professional misconduct and will be subjected to disciplinary action.

The important offences may be described as "the 6 A's". (1) Adultery arising out of professional relationship (2) Advertising (3) Abortion (unlawful) (4) Association with unqualified persons in professional matters (5) Addiction (6) Alcohol.

Offences under advertising include: 

  • A physician should not contribute to the lay press articles and give interviews regarding illnesses and treatments in an attempt to promote oneself. (option C)
  • He should not advertise himself through manufacturing firms directly or indirectly. (option D)
  • He should not put up a signboard at a pharmacy where he doesn't work. (option A)
  • It is illegal for a physician to use an unusually large signboard and write anything other than his name, qualifications, his speciality and registration number, including the name of the State Medical Council under which he is registered. His prescription papers should also have the same information.
  • A physician may notify the public or professional press of the beginning of his practice, the stoppage or resuming of it after a long period, or a change of address, but such a notification may appear no more than twice.

questions.text: Which of the following phospholipids plays a key role in the generation and transmission of visual impulses in the retina?
questions.solution:
Phosphatidylinositol (PI) is responsible for signal transmission as well as the generation of impulses in the retina. 

Rhodopsin or visual purple, the photosensitive pigment, is composed of opsin (a protein belonging to the superfamily of G protein–coupled receptors) and retinal (an aldehyde of vitamin A). When light strikes the photoreceptors, retinal is chemically transformed in a process called photoisomerization, which begins the transduction process.

Visual pigments are a type of G-protein-coupled receptors. The receptor protein, known as opsin, is locked in its inactive state by 11-cis retinal. Isomerization and photo-excitation result in the activation of G-protein and the production of cyclic GMP. Transducin serves as the G-protein specifically within the retina. The nerve impulse that is produced in the retina is then conveyed to the visual centres in the brain. The signal is ended through the process of phosphorylation, specifically targeting a serine residue on the activated rhodopsin. This phosphorylation is carried out by an enzyme called rhodopsin kinase. The purpose of this phosphorylation is to allow the inhibitory protein beta-arrestin to connect to the rhodopsin and deactivate it.

The phos­phorylation of membrane-bound phosphatidylinositol (PI) produces polyphosphoinositides such as phosphatidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate (PIP2).

The degradation of PIP2 by phospholipase C occurs in response to the binding of a variety of neurotransmitters, hormones, and growth factors to receptors on the cell membrane. The degrada­tion products are :

  • Inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate (IP3) which mediates the mobilization of intracellular calcium
  • Diacylglycerol (DAG) which activates protein kinase C

Both of these act synergistically to evoke specific cellular responses thus accomplishing signal transmission.

Other options:

Option A: Phosphatidylserine, a phospholipid, is a component of the cell membrane. It is composed of serine and phosphatidic acid. It plays a key role in cell cycle signalling, coagulation and apoptosis (programmed cell death).

Option C: Phosphatidylcholine is a major phospholipid in cell membranes, essential for maintaining structural integrity and signalling. It also plays a key role in lipid metabolism and is a precursor for acetylcholine, a neurotransmitter.

Option D: Phosphatidylethanolamine is a major phospholipid found in cell membranes, crucial for membrane stability and fusion. It also plays a role in lipid metabolism and supports cellular processes like autophagy.

questions.text: What is the active principle of the poison shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The image shows black, heart-shaped seeds with hard rinds that identify them as seeds of Semecarpus anacardium, and its active principles are bhilawanol and semicarpol. Common names are marking nut, bhilwan, bibva, bhela, and oriental cashew.

Within the fruit is a thick fleshy pericarp that yields the active principle, which is a brown oily resinous fluid called bhilawanol. 

The juice when applied locally to the skin produces irritation, painful blisters, itching, and eczematous eruption. The seeds are used to produce an artificial bruise. Symptoms such as pain, fever, and painful passage of brownish urine may be seen.

A large dose taken orally can produce blisters in the mouth and throat, with gastroenteritis. It also produces dyspnea, cyanosis, tachycardia, coma, and death. The fatal period is 12 to 24 hours.

Medicolegal importance is the use of the juice by malingerers to fabricate wounds. Instilled in the eyes it can cause conjunctivitis or ophthalmia due to its local irritant effect.

Other options:

Option A: Ricin is the active principle of Ricinus communis. It is a toxalbumin or phytotoxin that inhibits protein synthesis by affecting the ribosomal RNA polymerase. The seeds are flat to oval-shaped and have dark brown markings (shown below). It is a chemical warfare agent.

Option B: Abrin is the active principle of Abrus precatorius. The seeds are egg-shaped, scarlet in color, and have a black spot at one end (shown below). On ingestion, it causes gastroenteritis with bloody diarrhea, rectal bleeding, tachycardia, and circulatory collapse. Injecting the active substance can mimic viperine snakebite. Rarely, it may lead to tetanic convulsions. 

The seeds of A. precatorius are decocted and mixed with datura, opium, onion, spirit, and water to form a paste. From this, small sharp needles called suis are made. They are used for hunting animals and even for homicide purposes.

Option C: Thevetin is a cardiac poison derived from the plant Cerebra Thevetia (yellow oleander). All parts of the plant are poisonous. Symptoms of intoxication are characterized by vomiting, diarrhoea, headache, dizziness, mydriasis, and loss of muscular power. Cardiovascular signs include a weak and irregular pulse rate with hypotension. Possible complications are heart block and cardiorespiratory failure.

questions.text: Diseases in which clinical recovery does not coincide with bacteriological recovery give rise to which kind of carrier?
questions.solution:
Diseases in which clinical recovery does not coincide with bacteriological recovery give rise to the convalescent carrier.

In cases of typhoid fever, dysentery (bacillary and amebic), cholera, diphtheria, and whooping cough, patients continue to shed the disease agent during the period of recovery following an illness (convalescence). They pose a serious threat to unprotected household members and those in the immediate environment.

Other options:

Option A: Paradoxical carriers are carriers who acquired the pathogen from another carrier. Example: A carrier with subclinical polio infection acquired the pathogen from another household member, who is also a carrier for poliovirus.

Option B: Incubatory carriers are those who shed infectious agents during the incubation period and can carriers transmit the disease before the onset of symptoms. Examples: measles, mumps, polio, pertussis, influenza, diphtheria, and hepatitis B.

Option D: Healthy carriers acquire the infectious agent but do not develop any symptoms of disease and keep shedding the agent. Examples: Poliomyelitis, cholera, meningococcal meningitis, salmonellosis, and diphtheria.

questions.text: Which of the following vitamins is the most likely to be deficient in a patient with selenium deficiency ?
questions.solution:
Patients with selenium deficiency are most likely to have concomitant vitamin E deficiency.

Vitamin E is the most potent and naturally occurring antioxidant.

Protective antioxidant nutrients:

  • Vitamin E
  • Vitamin C
  • Vitamin A and the carotenoids
  • Selenium
  • Polyphenolic compounds derived from plant foods

Current therapeutic use of vitamin E is recommended in diseases causing fat malabsorption, severe pancreatic insufficiency, and cholestatic liver disease.
