questions.text: A child presented with diarrhea, cough, and wheezing for the past 6 months. He is underweight and stunted for his age. Blood tests showed mild eosinophilia. The appearance of eggs in the stool specimen is shown below. The likely cause is?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing an oval egg with rhabditiform larvae indicate infection by Strongyloides stercoralis.

The worm is ovoviviparous. The eggs contain fully formed larvae that hatch out immediately.

 Characteristics of the egg of Strongyloides stercoralis:

  • Thin-walled
  • Transparent
  • Ovoid in shape
  • Contain the rhabditiform (first stage) larva.

It is unique among human nematodes as it has a parasitic cycle and a free-living soil cycle, during which it persists for a long duration in the soil. The image given below shows the life cycle of Strongyloides stercoralis.

The infective form of Strongyloides is the filariform larva. When a person walks barefoot on soil containing the infective filariform larvae, they penetrate the skin and enter the circulation. Then, they migrate to the small intestine.

Here, the larvae moult twice and become adult female worms. The eggs laid by the female in the intestinal mucosa hatch immediately releasing the rhabditiform larva (L1 stage). These rhabditiform larvae in the bowel can develop directly into filariform larvae that penetrate the colonic wall or perianal skin and enter the circulation to repeat the migration. This establishes ongoing internal reinfection.

This autoinfection is not seen in Ancylostoma or Necator life cycle.

Strongyloidiasis (infection caused by S. stercoralis) is generally benign and asymptomatic. The clinical disease may have cutaneous (dermatitis at the site of penetration, perianal pruritis, urticaria), pulmonary (bronchopneumonia, chronic bronchitis, asthma) and intestinal manifestations (mucus diarrhea, dysentery).

The rhabditiform larva (not the egg) in feces can be seen under a microscope, and eosinophilia in the blood is diagnostic of the disease.

Other options:

Option A: Ascaris lumbricoides is a large intestinal worm, and its ova are typically seen in the stool, not larvae. It is not commonly associated with chronic diarrhoea, especially in immunocompromised patients. 

Option B: Trichuris trichiura is also known as whipworm. The infective form is the embryonated egg that contains a rhabditiform larva. Patients are often asymptomatic except when the worm load is heavy where the disease manifests due to mechanical effects or allergic reactions. Fecal smears show a barrel-shaped ovum with a mucus plug at both ends. Eggs of Trichuris trichiura are brown in color, bile stained, and float in a saturated salt solution. 

Option C: Enterobius vermicularis, also known as pinworm, lives in the cecum and appendix. Infection is by ingestion of eggs or autoinfection. Detection of eggs by NIH swabs and cellophane scotch tape method. 

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

questions.text: What is the action of the superior oblique muscle?
questions.solution:
The actions carried out by the superior oblique muscle are intorsion, depression, and abduction.

There are six extraocular muscles for each eye. Four rectus muscles namely - superior, inferior, medial, and lateral recti. The oblique muscles are two - superior oblique and inferior oblique. These muscles are responsible for the movements of the eye which can be either unilateral or binocular movements.

The superior oblique muscle originates from the apex of the orbit, turns around the trochlea, and inserts into the sclera behind the equator. The oblique direction of the tendon is responsible for its rotatory effect (intorsion), in addition to depression and abduction.

 

Unilateral movements (ductions) are :

1.Adduction: It is the movement towards the nasal side around the vertical axis.

2.Abduction: It is the movement towards the temporal side around the vertical axis.

3.Supraduction (elevation): It is upward movement around the horizontal axis.

4.Infraduction (depression): It is downward movement around the horizontal axis.

5.Intorsion (medial rotation): Rotatory movement along the anteroposterior axis where the superior pole of cornea moves medially.

6.Extorsion (lateral rotation): Rotatory movement along the anteroposterior axis where the superior pole of cornea moves laterally.

Binocular movements can be of two types - versions and vergences.

The oculomotor nerve supplies all the extraocular muscles except the superior oblique and lateral rectus. The superior oblique muscle is supplied by the trochlear nerve and lateral rectus muscle by the abducent nerve.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions can be best evaluated by the radiographic view given below?
questions.solution:
The given radiographic image demonstrates the occipitofrontal view or Caldwell view. It is the best view for visualizing the frontal sinus and can thus be used to evaluate frontal sinusitis

The Caldwell view is taken with the nose and forehead touching the film (also called the nose-forehead position) and the X-ray beam projected at 15-20 degrees caudally (demonstrated below). 

The frontal sinuses are seen best using this view. This view can thus be useful for the evaluation of frontal sinusitis, frontal bone osteomyelitis, frontal sinus cysts. The other structures that can also be evaluated using this condition include maxillary sinuses, ethmoid sinuses, the zygoma, superior margins of the orbit, and superior orbital fissure. 

Other options:
Mastoid abscess (Option A) can be best evaluated using Schuller's view. It is a lateral radiographic view of the skull that best evaluates the mastoid antrum and upper part of the attic. It is used for the evaluation of mastoiditis, mastoid abscess, cholesteatoma, and post-mastoidectomy cavity. 

Acoustic neuroma (Option B) can be best evaluated using Towne's view. It is an angled anteroposterior radiograph of the skull that shows both petrous pyramids, arcuate eminence, superior semicircular canal, mastoid antrum, internal auditory canal, tympanic cavity, cochlea, and external auditory canal. This view is used for the evaluation of acoustic neuroma and apical petrositis.

Temporal bone fracture (Option D) can be evaluated using radiographic views used to evaluate the temporal bone. These include the Law's view, Schuller's view, Stenver's view, and the trans-orbital view.

questions.text: Choose the correct option regarding the following graph.

choices.text: Point C represents the value which occurs with greatest frequency
Here the mode is greater than the mean
It is a positively skewed distribution
Point B represents the mean of the distribution

questions.solution:
This is an example of a left-skewed or negatively skewed distribution, and shows the relation between mean, median and mode as Mode>median > mean.

The relationship among the three measures of central tendency depends on the shape of the distribution. All three measures are identical in an unimodal symmetrical distribution (such as the normal distribution), so Mean=Median =Mode. In a skewed distribution, the three variables of central tendency are not equal.

In a positively skewed/ right-skewed distribution, the mode is simply the most frequently occurring score (the highest point on the curve); the mean is pulled up by the influence of a relatively small number of very high scores; and the median lies between the two, dividing the distribution into two equal areas under the curve. On the curve mean > median > mode.

Conversely, in a negatively skewed/ left-skewed distribution, the mode is again the most frequently occurring score (the highest point on the curve); the mean is pulled down by the influence of a relatively small number of very low scores; and the median lies between the two. On the curve, we find mean < median < mode.

  • Figure (c) in the following image shows a positively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the positive direction. In this, the mean will be larger than the median and mode, i.e., mean > median > mode.

questions.text:
A woman who came to the ENT OPD was tested with the instrument given below for impaired hearing. Which of the following tests can be performed with this instrument?
  1. Weber test
  2. Schwabach’s test
  3. Threshold Tone Decay Test
  4. Gelle’s test
  5. Short Increment Sensitivity Index
questions.solution:
The instrument given in the image is a tuning fork. Weber test, Schwabach’s test, and Gelle’s test can be done with a tuning fork.

Tuning fork tests are performed commonly with tuning forks of frequencies such as 128, 256, 512, 1024, etc. The tuning fork of 512 Hz is considered ideal as forks of lower frequencies produce a sense of bone vibration, while those of higher frequencies have a shorter decay time. Some examples of commonly done tuning fork tests are as follows:

Weber test is done by placing a vibrating tuning in the middle of the forehead or the vertex and the patient is asked in which ear the sound is better heard. The inferences are as follows:

  • It is reported as normal when the sound is heard equally in both ears
  • In conductive deafness, it is lateralized to the worse ear.
  • In sensorineural deafness, it is lateralized to the better ear.

In Schwabach's test, the bone conduction of the patient is compared with that of the examiner but unlike the absolute bone conduction test, the EAC is not occluded. Inferences are as follows:

  • Normal: The test result is the same as that of the examiner
  • Conductive deafness: Test result is lengthier than that of the examiner
  • Sensorineural deafness: Test result is shorter than that of the examiner

Gelle’s test is a test of bone conduction and examines the effect of increased air pressure in the ear canal on hearing. Normally, when air pressure is increased in the ear canal by Siegel’s speculum, it pushes the tympanic membrane and ossicles inwards. This raises the intralabyrinthine pressure and causes immobility of the basilar membrane and decreased hearing. But, no change in hearing is observed when the ossicular chain is fixed or disconnected. Gelle’s test is positive in normal persons and in those with sensorineural hearing loss.

The threshold tone decay test is a measure of nerve fatigue. A Tone of 4000Hz is presented at 5dB above the patient’s threshold of hearing for 60 seconds. A normal ear can hear continuously for a minute but a patient with abnormal hearing stops hearing before 1 minute. Loudness is increased until the patient can hear the sound. A decay of more than 25 dB is diagnostic of a retrocochlear lesion.

A normal ear can’t differentiate short increments of sound but a recruiting ear can. The Short Increment Sensitivity Index (SISI )test is started with a sound of 20db above the hearing threshold of the patient and 20 increments of 1db are given every 5 seconds. The total number of increments heard by the patient is recorded. A SISI score of 70-100% is seen in cochlear deafness and 0-20% in retro cochlear deafness.

questions.text: Which of the following ion channels in peripheral chemoreceptors is oxygen-sensitive?
questions.solution:
Potassium channels in the peripheral chemoreceptors are oxygen-sensitive. 

Type I glomus cells (carotid and aortic body) have O2-sensitive K+ channels, whose conductance is reduced in proportion to the degree of hypoxia.

This reduces the K+ efflux, depolarizing the cell and causing Ca2+ inﬂux. 

Hypoxia induces vasoconstriction by inhibition of oxygen-sensitive potassium channels in pulmonary vascular smooth muscle cell membranes. This leads to depolarization of the cell membrane and activation of calcium channels causing the influx of calcium ions. The Ca2+ influx triggers action potentials and consequent excitation of the afferent nerve endings and constriction of small arteries and arterioles.

When the concentration of O2 in the alveoli decreases below normal the adjacent blood vessels constrict. This effect is opposite to the effect observed in systemic vessels, which dilate rather than constrict in response to low O2 levels.

This is because the low oxygen concentrations can :

  • Stimulate the release of or increase sensitivity to vasoconstrictor substances such as endothelin or reactive oxygen species.
  • Decrease the release of vasodilators such as nitric oxide from the lung.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman with a 2-month history of cough and shortness of breath is found to have bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy on a chest X-ray. She also complains of dry eyes and nodules in the skin over her arms. Which of the following findings can be seen in the biopsy of her lymph nodes?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a woman with bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, a history of cough, dry eyes, nodules in the skin over her arms, points to a diagnosis of sarcoidosis. In this condition, naked granuloma can be seen on lymph node biopsy.

Sarcoidosis is a systemic granulomatous disease that most commonly presents as bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. Lesions of the eyes and skin are also very common in these patients. It is seen more in middle-aged women than in men.

Sarcoidosis results from an increase in CD4+ T-cells (increased CD4+:CD8+ ratio). As a result, cytokines like IL-2, TNF, IL-8, and IFN-gamma will increase. These cytokines are the cause of granuloma formation in this disorder.

It presents with granulomas in multiple organs. They are classically described as non-caseating granulomas composed of epithelioid macrophages with giant cells. There is no central necrosis as there would be in tubercular granulomas. Naked granulomas are non-caseating granulomas minimally surrounded by lymphocytes.

Laminated calcium and protein-containing bodies called Schaumann bodies (shown in the image below) and star-shaped inclusions called asteroid bodies are also found in the giant cells of most of these granulomas. These are not pathognomonic to sarcoidosis and can also be found in other granulomatous diseases like tuberculosis.

Other options:

Option A: Stellate granulomas are granulomas containing central granular debris and neutrophils. They are characteristically seen in cat-scratch disease caused by B. henselae.

The image below shows stellate granuloma

Option B: Foreign body granulomas are incited by relatively inert foreign bodies, such as talc, sutures. Epithelioid cells and giant cells are apposed to the surface of the foreign body. The foreign material can usually be identified in the center of the granuloma.

The given image shows suture granuloma. The suture material is surrounded by lymphocytic infiltration

Option C: Durck granulomas are seen in cerebral malaria.

questions.text: A patient presents with persistent nasal congestion for the last four weeks. He has been using intranasal decongestants for the last three weeks which initially provided relief. However, his symptoms recurred after two weeks of treatment. What is the next step in management for this condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with recurrent symptoms of nasal congestion after initial improvement with intranasal decongestants is likely to have rhinitis medicamentosa. The next step in management for this condition is stopping the use of intranasal decongestants. 

Rhinitis medicamentosa is also known as rebound congestion. It occurs due to overuse of topical nasal decongestants which leads to inflammation of the nasal mucosa. It occurs when decongestants are used for more than 7-10 days. The exact etiology is not known. 

Patients usually present with severe nasal congestion and nasal mucosa swelling that has an erythematous and granular appearance. 

It is treated by discontinuing the decongestant. This may lead to an initial worsening of symptoms which can be relieved by using intranasal corticosteroids. Some may also prescribe short-course oral corticosteroids, oral antihistamines, and inferior turbinate steroid injections but are not frequently recommended.

questions.text: The time interval between the receipt of infection by a host and maximal infectivity of that host is known as ______
questions.solution:
The time interval between the receipt of infection by a host and the maximal infectivity of that host is known as the generation time.

The time of maximum communicability may precede or follow the incubation period. In the case of mumps, the maximum communicability appears to reach its height about 48 hours before the onset of swelling of the salivary glands.

Option A: Lead time is the period between the first possible time of detection and the usual time of diagnosis.

Option B: Serial interval is the gap in time between the onset of the primary case and the second case. The term serial interval is used in an outbreak of disease.

Option D: Screening time is the time difference between the first point of diagnosis and the critical point of diagnosis. Screening must be done in conditions where there is a considerable time lag between the onset of disease and the usual time of diagnosis.

questions.text: An infant is brought by his parents with complaints that his urine turns black on standing. Which of the following metabolic disorders is likely?
questions.solution:
Blackening of urine on standing is characteristic of alkaptonuria.

Alkaptonuria is an autosomal recessive disorder of tyrosine metabolism, that develops due to the defect in homogentisate oxidase/homogentisic acid 1, 2 - dioxygenase, which oxidizes homogentisate to maleylacetoacetate. The defect in this enzyme leads to the accumulation of homogentisate, which is then excreted in the urine. 

Alkaptonuria is characterized by homogentisic aciduria, ochronosis, and arthropathy (joint pain).

Homogentisic aciduria is the black discoloration of urine on prolonged exposure to air caused due to oxidation of the excreted homogentisate. 

Ochronosis, which is bluish-black pigmentation in connective tissue, generally occurs after the third decade of life, and it occurs due to the accumulation of homogentisic acid and its oxidation products like benzoquinone acetic acid in connective tissue.

Arthritis generally begins in the third decade. Arthritis often begins in the spine and resembles ankylosing spondylitis in its large-joint distribution. Radiographs of the spine showing flattened and calcified intervertebral discs are pathognomonic. Other findings include degeneration of the intervertebral discs, followed by disc calcification and eventually fusion of the vertebral bodies. Osteophyte formation and calcification of the intervertebral ligaments also occur.

Diagnosis: Blackish discoloration of urine on standing is diagnostic of alkaptonuria (shown below). The ferric chloride test will be positive. The blackening of urine occurs due to the excretion of homogentisic acid in the urine.

Image A - Normal urine
Image B - Alkaptonuria

Other options:

Option A: Phenylketonuria (PKU) is a metabolic disorder resulting from a deficiency of the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase. It does not lead to black urine. Patients with PKU have a musty or mousy odor due to phenylacetic acid accumulation.

Option C: Homocystinuria is an inborn error of methionine metabolism caused by a deficiency of the enzyme cystathionine β-synthase. It is characterized by tall stature, long limbs, dislocation of the lens of the eye, and predisposition to thromboembolism, but it does not lead to black urine.

Option D: Maple syrup urine disease (MSUD) is an inherited metabolic disorder caused by a deficiency of branched-chain α-ketoacid dehydrogenase. It does not cause black urine. Patients with MSUD have urine with a characteristic sweet odor, resembling maple syrup.

questions.text: A 39-year-old man presented with burning pain in his lower extremities along with staggering gait and sleep disturbances. Which of the following vitamins is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario is burning feet syndrome. Vitamin B5-pantothenic acid is responsible for this condition.

Burning foot syndrome presents as burning and lightning pain in the lower extremities, staggering gait due to impaired coordination, and sleep disturbances. It was first seen in prisoners during the second world war. Other features of pantothenic acid deficiency include GI disturbances, paraesthesia, muscle cramps, and ataxia. Burning feet syndrome or nutritional melalgia was first seen in prisoners during the second world war.

Pantothenic acid contains beta-alanine. Beta-alanine is seen in Pantothenic acid (vitamin B5), Coenzyme A, carnosine, anserine, and acyl carrier protein.

Other options:

Option A: Vitamin B6 status can be assessed by assaying erythrocyte transaminase which is activated by pyridoxal phosphate. Deficiency may present with seizures, mental status changes, normocytic anemia, a nonspecific pruritic rash, cheilitis, glossitis, and depression. Excess vitamin B6 causes sensory neuropathy.  It occurs at intakes above 2 g/day

Option B: Deficiency of riboflavin is characterized by cheilosis, desquamation, inflammation of the tongue, seborrheic dermatitis, corneal vascularization, anemia, and personality changes. Riboflavin nutritional status is assessed by measurement of the activation of erythrocyte glutathione reductase by FAD added in vitro.

Option D: The most important function of vitamin E (Tocopherol) is its chain-breaking antioxidant role. In vitamin E deficiency, there is no prevention of lipid peroxidation caused due to free radicals. As a result of this, the erythrocyte membranes are rendered abnormally fragile leading to hemolytic anemia. It can lead to ataxia, difficulty with upward gaze, hyporeflexia, and profuse muscle weakness.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman came with complaints of headache and nasal discharge since 1 week. She describes the headache to be present as soon as she wakes up, gradually increasing until midday, and then starting to subside. What is the site of drainage of the structure affected in the above case?
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario, the duration of symptoms and the characteristic pattern of headache described are highly suggestive of acute frontal sinusitis, caused by inflammation in frontal sinus cavities, which drain into the middle meatus of the nose.

It is most often associated with an antecedent viral upper respiratory tract infection followed later by bacterial invasion. 

Patients present with frontal headache with characteristic periodicity i.e. present on waking up, gradually increases and reaches its peak by about midday and then starts subsiding. It is also called “office headache” because of its presence only during office hours.

Treatment: Medical - Antimicrobials, decongestion of the sinus ostium and a combination of antihistaminic with oral nasal decongestant (phenylephrine hydrochloride).  Surgical- Trephination of the frontal sinus.

Paranasal sinuses are air-containing cavities that are present in the skull bones. These paranasal sinuses have been divided into two groups:

Anterior group: Their ostia drain into the middle meatus through a common drainage pathway known as osteomeatal unit. This group includes:

  • Maxillary sinus (antrum of Highmore)
  • Frontal sinus
  • Anterior ethmoidal sinus

Posterior group: 

  • Posterior ethmoidal sinuses: Opens in the superior meatus (option A)
  • Sphenoid sinus: Opens in sphenoethmoidal recess (option B)

The inferior meatus (option C) has the nasolacrimal duct draining into it with its terminal end being guarded by the Hasner's valve.

  • Superior meatus: Posterior ethmoidal sinus
  • Sphenoethmoidal recess: Sphenoid sinus

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman who is a known case of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS) presents with severe abdominal pain, hypotension, and decreased level of consciousness. On further examination, colonic artery rupture was discovered. This occurs due to the defects in which type of collagen in EDS?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes a typical case of vascular type of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS) that occurs due to defects in type III collagen.

EDS is a connective tissue disorder occuring due to genetic defects involved in collagen synthesis and action. It is characterized by hyperextensibility of skin, hypermobile joints, easy bruising, and poor wound healing.

The vascular variant of EDS has an autosomal dominant mode of inheritance. It was previously known as type IV EDS. It results from defects in type III collagen and occurs due to a mutation in the COL3A1 gene. Unlike other types of EDS, hyperextensibility of skin is absent in the vascular type of EDS. The skin is thin and translucent with visible veins. Other features of vascular EDS include arterial rupture, uterine rupture, bruising, and small joint hyperextensibility.

The collagen defects in other variants of EDS are:

  • Arthrochalasia and dermatosparaxis EDS: Defective conversion of type I procollagen to collagen
  • Classical EDS: Mutation in the gene encoding type V collagen

questions.text: A 20-year-old female presented with abdominal pain, arthralgia, tendon xanthomas, and xanthelasma. Laboratory investigation revealed elevated total cholesterol levels. Genetic testing revealed a mutation in ABCG5 and ABCG8. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario and the genetic testing showing mutations in ABCG5 and ABCG8 points to the diagnosis of sitosterolemia.

It is an inherited condition in which the body absorbs an excessive amount of plant sterols. ATP-binding cassette transporter helps in the transport of sterols into the gut lumen once they enter the gastrointestinal cells. In a person with sitosterolemia, the ABC transporter is defective. Hence, the plant sterols are not transported into the gut lumen and the liver cannot excrete sterols into the bile as effectively. This results in excessive accumulation of plant sterols in the individual's blood which can lead to premature heart disease and other complications.

The genes ABCG5 and ABCG8 encode for the ABC transporter proteins. Clinical features are tendon xanthomas, corneal arcus, xanthelasma, abdominal pain, and arthralgia. Laboratory investigations show increased total cholesterol levels.

Management involves significant dietary modifications. Intake of vegetable oils, nuts, and avocados should be reduced. Ezetimibe is approved for the treatment.

Other options:

Option B: Tangier’s disease is a hypolipoproteinemia caused by a mutation of the ABCA1 gene. Enlarged orange tonsils are pathognomonic. Low HDL levels are seen. Clinical features of Tangier disease include hyperplastic yellow-orange tonsils, hepatosplenomegaly, and peripheral neuropathy, which may be either relapsing-remitting or chronic progressive in nature

Option C: Lipoprotein lipase (LPL) deficiency causes hyperchylomicronemia (type I hyperlipoproteinemia) due to defects in LPL or apo C-II. Eruptive xanthomas are seen. Chylomicrons and VLDL are elevated. LDL and HDL are low. There is no risk of coronary disease. Instead, patients have an increased risk of acute pancreatitis. This is due to very high triglyceride levels. It can also cause a milky appearance of plasma.

Option D: Type III hyperlipoproteinemia is also known as broad β-disease, remnant removal disease, or familial dysbetalipoproteinemia. Type III hyperlipoproteinemia is caused by a defective ApoE that mediated the removal of lipoprotein remnants. Clinical features include hypercholesterolemia, xanthomas, and atherosclerosis. There is an increase in remnant chylomicrons, remnant VLDL (i.e.Intermediate-density lipoprotein), cholesterol, and triglyceride levels. Fibrates are effective in treating patients with type III hyperlipoproteinemia.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male patient presented to the clinic with a history of diarrhoea and poor appetite. He has been having 4-5 episodes of non-bloody, loose stools per day for the last 3 months. A duodenal biopsy is taken and the histopathology is shown below. Which of the following statements is false about this given condition?

choices.text: MARSH score is used for diagnosis of this condition
Histopathological study reveals raised intraepithelial macrophages
Anti-endomysial antibodies is associated with this condition

questions.solution:
The given scenario of diarrhoea and poor appetite and histopathology findings (explained below) are suggestive of celiac disease. Histopathological study reveals raised intraepithelial lymphocytes.

Celiac disease or celiac sprue or gluten-sensitive enteropathy is triggered by the ingestion of gluten, which is the major storage protein of wheat and similar grains. It usually affects the 2nd part of the duodenum or proximal jejunum. 

MARSH's score is used to assess celiac disease histologically. 

Dermatitis herpetiformis occurs in about 10% of patients with celiac disease.

Diagnosis:

  • The single best screening test for Celiac disease is Tissue Transglutaminase Ab (tTG-IgA) which has a sensitivity of about 98% & specificity of about 95%. 
  • Anti-gliadin antibodies are produced in response to gliadin, a component found in wheat. Antigliadin antibody tests (AGA-IgA and AGA-IgG) have lower diagnostic accuracy.  
  • HLA-DQ2 or DQ8 are present in most patients with celiac disease. HLA testing has a positive predictive value of 12 percent. Hence, HLA testing is useful only in ruling out celiac disease.   
  • Endoscopy with small bowel biopsy is used as a confirmatory test to diagnose celiac disease and not as an initial test in suspected cases.
  • The histopathology is characterized by villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, and increased intraepithelial CD8+T lymphocytes. An increase in the number of intraepithelial lymphocytes is a sensitive marker of celiac disease, even in the absence of epithelial damage and villous atrophy. MARSH's Score is used to assess celiac disease histologically. 

    Dermatitis herpetiformis can occur in as many as 10% of patients.

    The mainstay of treatment is a gluten-free diet.

questions.text: The banding technique used for staining the telomeres of chromosomes is:
questions.solution:
The banding technique used for staining the telomeres of chromosomes is T banding.

Karyotyping is the process by which chromosomes are isolated, stained, and examined to find chromosomal anomalies. It is used in prenatal diagnosis, investigation of repeat pregnancy loss, investigation of children and adults suspected of having a chromosomal disorder, and subtyping of lymphomas and leukemias for the purpose of exact diagnosis, giving a prognosis, and treatment. Various techniques are used in karyotyping to study chromosomes. Staining with various compounds produces various results and helps us to understand the chromosomes better. Common techniques used are:

  • G banding - Giemsa staining after partial denaturation of chromatin. It is the most common technique used in cytogenetics to produce a visible karyotype.
  • R banding - Reverse Giemsa staining. In this, the light and dark areas are reversed
  • C banding - Staining of heterochromatin with silver salts
  • T banding - Staining the telomeres of chromosomes

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is not included in NP-NCD?
questions.solution:

The NPCDCS (National Program for Prevention and Control of Cancer, Diabetes, Cardiovascular Diseases and Stroke) has been changed to NP-NCP (National Program for Prevention and Control of Non-Communicable Diseases). questions.text: A 5-year-old child with a ​history of perianal pain is brought to the OPD. On subjecting the specimen from the perianal region to a test, it produces yellow rhombic crystals of spermine picrate. What is the test done?
questions.solution:
The test done in the scenario is Barberio test. It is used to detect seminal fluid.

When saturated aqueous or alcoholic solution of picric acid is added to the spermatic fluid, yellow needle-shaped rhombic crystals of spermine picrate are produced.

Other options: 

Option B: Florence test: 

  • The suspected seminal stain is extracted with 10% hydrochloric acid and a drop of it is placed over a slide.
  • A coverslip is placed over it and a drop of Florence solution (potassium iodide, iodine, and water) is made to run under the coverslip.
  • If semen is present, dark brown rhombic or needle-shaped crystals of choline iodide appear immediately.

Option C: Takayama test (Haemochromogen crystal test): 

  • The test is used to detect suspected bloodstains. Small piece of suspected material is added on a glass slide.
  • Then, 2-3 drops of Takayama reagent is added and covered with a coverslip.
  • If it is a bloodstain, pink feathery crystals of hemochromogen or reduced alkaline haematin appear in a few minutes.

Option D: Teichmann test (Haemin Crystal Test): 

  • The test is used to detect suspected bloodstains.
  • Small piece of suspected material is placed on a glass slide. Then, 2-3 drops of glacial acetic acid and a small crystal of sodium chloride are added to the glass slide and covered with a coverslip. The slide is then heated.
  • If bloodstain is present, faint yellowish-red to brownish-black rhombic crystals of haemin or haematin chloride appear.
  • When hydrogen peroxide is added, the haematin crystals give bubbles of gas.

questions.text: Which of the following nomograms is used for paracetamol poisoning ?
questions.solution:
Rumack Matthew nomogram is used in paracetamol poisoning. In this nomogram serum acetaminophen concentration is measured for the time after ingestion which is useful in assessing potential hepatotoxicity after an acute ingestion of paracetamol.

Acetaminophen toxicity clinically presents with nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal pain. Later, renal failure and myocardial injury may be seen. Low bilirubin levels along with raised aminotransferase levels are characteristic of the condition. 

Acetaminophen toxicity is an important cause of acute liver failure. Ingestion of ≥25g can be fatal. Cytochrome P450 CYP2E1 metabolizes acetaminophen to N-acetyl-p-benzoquinone-imine (NAPQI). Glutathione is responsible for its detoxification, after which it is excreted in the urine. When glutathione reserves are depleted or large amounts of NAPQI are formed, it binds to hepatocyte macromolecules. This can then lead to hepatocyte necrosis.

Initial management includes gastric lavage and oral charcoal or cholestyramine. It should be carried out within thirty minutes of ingestion. If they are used, gastric lavage must be done afterwards before using another agent. Acetaminophen blood levels can be estimated from a nomogram plot. In patients with high acetaminophen levels, intravenous N-acetylcysteine administration within 8 hours of ingestion is recommended. It helps in the replenishment of glutathione. It is partially effective even up to 36 hours. Liver transplantation is necessary if signs of hepatic failure continue despite therapy. 

Other option(s):

questions.text: A middle-aged-man presents with right hypochondriac pain and yellowish discoloration of eyes. His ultrasound is as shown in the image below. Which of the following is true about the causative agent of his condition?

choices.text: Sheep is the ideal definitive host
The larval stage is found in dogs
Mode of infection is by skin penetration

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the USG showing a cyst with detached membranes (water lily sign) are suggestive of a hydatid cyst. Hydatid disease or echinococcosis is caused by the Echinococcus species of flatworms. Humans are accidental hosts in their life cycle.

The life cycle of Echinococcus consists of dog (optimal host) and wolf as the definitive hosts, sheep (Option A) and cattle as intermediate hosts. Sheep is the ideal intermediate host because transmission occurs when hydatid cysts from sheep carcasses are eaten by dogs in slaughterhouses. The mode of infection is by the feco-oral route. Humans get infected (Option D) following the ingestion of food items contaminated with dog faeces containing the eggs of Echinococcus. Man acts as an accidental intermediate host (dead end).

The larval stage(Option B) of the parasite is passed in intermediate hosts, including man, giving rise to a hydatid cyst, which usually develops three weeks after the infection.

The life cycle of Echinococcus granulosus is as shown in the image below:

The hydatid cyst wall consists of 3 layers:

Pericyst- the outer dense fibrous capsule that is formed as a result of host inflammatory response.
Ectocyst- the intermediate layer consisting of acellular, chitinous, laminated hyaline material.
Endocyst- the inner germinal layer that is cellular and consists of a number of nuclei embedded in protoplasmic mass and is extremely thin. It is the vital layer of the cyst and it is the site of asexual reproduction giving rise to brood capsules with scolices.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic male patient presents with oral lesions that cannot be scraped off and is given below. Identify the false statement regarding this condition from the following.

choices.text: It is seen equally in males and females
Erythroplakia is more serious than the given lesion
Unless proven otherwise all the patients with this lesion are considered premalignant
Lesions can occur anywhere in the oral cavity

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a chronic alcoholic male patient with oral lesions characterized by whitish patches or plaques that cannot be rubbed off is leukoplakia. Leukoplakia is seen more commonly in males with a ratio of 2:1.

Leukoplakia is a premalignant condition (unless proven otherwise) of the oral cavity that can occur anywhere in the oral cavity (buccal mucosa, floor of the mouth, ventral surface of the tongue, palate, and gingiva) characterized by whitish patches or plaques that cannot be rubbed off. They appear as small, well-circumscribed lesions and can extensively involve a large area of the oral mucosa.

Variants of leukoplakia are:

  • Speckled leukoplakia is whitish lesions on an erythematous base. They have the highest risk of malignant transformation. 
  • Proliferative verrucous leukoplakia is rare and has a high risk for malignant transformation.

Management includes smoking cessation and reduction in alcohol consumption. A biopsy should be done and a photographic record of the lesion is used for follow-up.

Erthroplakia refers to irregular, reddish velvety plaques on the oral cavity. The surface may be nodular and may bleed. It is less prevalent than leukoplakia but has a higher risk of malignant transformation (option B). Biopsy should be done followed by surgical ablation.

questions.text: Which of the following parameters is used for measuring the endemicity of malaria in a community?
questions.solution:
The spleen rate is used for measuring the endemicity of malaria in a community.

The spleen rate refers to the percentage of children aged 2 to 10 years showing an enlarged spleen. Surveys focusing on spleen enlargement exclude adults since various factors other than malaria can cause splenic enlargement in this population. The spleen rate is a commonly employed measure measuring the endemicity of malaria in a community.

Other options:

Option A: The slide positivity rate represents the proportion of slides that test positive for the presence of malarial parasites, regardless of the specific species. It provides information on the trend of malaria transmission.

Option C: The annual blood examination rate is the percentage of the number of slides examined in a population. It is an index of operational efficiency.

Option D: The annual parasitic incidence (API) is a method of assessing the incidence of malaria within a community. It involves comprehensive active and passive surveillance, with confirmed cases determined through blood examinations. In India, regions with an API≥2 per 1000 population per year are categorized as high-risk areas, making them eligible for targeted vector control measures.

Related Pearl: National Strategic Plan for Malaria Elimination 2017 - 2022

  • The National Strategic Plan (NSP) for Malaria Elimination (2017-22) was launched by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare under NVBDCP, which is based on the National Framework for Malaria Elimination (2016 – 2030).
  • The NSP focuses mainly on the districts which function as the operational units.

Accordingly all the districts are classified into the following four categories

Category of districts Definition
Category 0: Prevention of re-establishment phase  Includes all districts in which no incidence of malaria was reported in last three years.
Category 1: Elimination phase  District in which annual parasite incidence (API), is less than one per 1000 population.
Category 2: Pre elimination phase  Districts with API in between one and two per 1000 population.
Category 3: Intensified control phase  Districts having API more than two.

The above classification is more operational than the classification mentioned in the NFME which is state focussed.

The goals of NSP strategy are phased elimination of malaria in India. The National Framework for Malaria Elimination (NFME) in India has set 2030 as goal for eliminating malaria, and the goals of NSP in consonance with overall goals.

The goals of NSP 2017 – 2022 are:

  • Eliminate malaria in category 1 (API < 1) districts by 2020, and category 2 (API 1 - 2) districts by 2022.
  • Reduce transmission in category 3 districts to stabilize API at less than 1 by 2022

Related Pearl: Malaria in the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP)

National Framework for Malaria Elimination in India (2016)

  • Goals: To eliminate malaria and maintain malaria-free status.
  • Objectives:
    • By 2022, transmission of malaria interrupted and zero indigenous cases.
    • By 2024, incidence of malaria to be reduced to less than 1 case per 1000 population.
    • By 2030, malaria to be eliminated throughout the country.

Category 2  Pre-elimination phase – States/UTs with API <1 but some districts reporting API ≥ 1. 

Screening. 

Setting up one-stop mobile centres/clinics.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with hypocalcemia, thymic hypoplasia, cardiac abnormalities, and deletion of chromosome 22q11.2 ?
questions.solution:
The given symptoms of hypocalcemia, developmental defect of the thymus, cardiac abnormalities, and deletion of chromosome 22q11.2 are suggestive of DiGeorge syndrome.

In this syndrome, the fourth branchial arch and the derivatives of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches (which contribute to the formation of the thymus, parathyroids, and heart) develop abnormally. This syndrome is therefore associated with multiple deficits (memorable through the mnemonic CATCH - 22)

Mnemonic CATCH-22:

  • Cardiac abnormality
  • Abnormal facies
  • Thymic aplasia
  • Cleft palate
  • Hypocalcemia
  • Deletion 22q11.2  

Thymic hypoplasia with impaired T cell immunity can manifest as:

  • T cells are absent in the lymph nodes, spleen, and peripheral blood, and infants with this defect are extremely vulnerable to viral, fungal, and protozoal infections.
  • Patients also are susceptible to infection with intracellular bacteria, because of defective T cell-mediated immunity.
  • B cells and serum immunoglobulins are generally unaffected.

 Other options:

Option A: Pitt syndrome or Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome or Pitt–Rogers–Danks syndrome (PRDS) occurs due to partial deletion or monosomy of chromosome 4. The main features of Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome are typical “Greek helmet” facies secondary to ocular hypertelorism, prominent glabella, and frontal bossing and microcephaly.

Option B: Williams syndrome occurs due to deletion at chromosome 7. Classical facial features include:

  • Periorbital fullness of subcutaneous tissues,
  • Hypertelorism,
  • A stellate pattern of the iris,
  • Long philtrum,
  • Thick vermillion border of the lips,
  • Wide mouth,
  • Small jaw (elfin facies)

Option D: Cri-du-chat syndrome is caused by the partial deletion of the short arm of Chromosome no.5. Affected children have a cat-like cry, microcephaly, mental retardation, and congenital heart disease.

Related Pearl: Clinical features of DiGeorge syndrome- Mnemonic

DiGeorge syndrome is a cellular immunodeficiency disorder caused by the deletion of a small segment of chromosome 22 (22q11) leading to a developmental defect involving the endodermal derivatives of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches. (Thymus and parathyroid glands)

The clinical features can be remembered with the mnemonic – CATCH

  • C – Cardiac defects
  • A – Abnormal facies
  • T – Thymic aplasia
  • C – Cleft palate
  • H – Hypocalcemia

questions.text: Which of the following consumes the highest energy during assimilation?
questions.solution:
Proteins consume the highest energy during assimilation.

The energy wasted in the assimilation of food is represented as diet-induced thermogenesis or specific dynamic action(SDA). Diet-induced thermogenesis (DIT) can be defined as the increase in energy expenditure above the basal metabolic rate and is expressed as a percentage.

The values for diet-induced thermogenesis are relatively higher protein and alcohol consumption and lower at a high-fat consumption, the hierarchy for it, being in the sequence of alcohol> protein> fat> carbohydrate. The value of DIT for protein is 30%, the lipid is 15% and carbohydrate is 5%. Hence, taking into account the loss of energy as DIT, additional 10% calories should be provided in a mixed diet.

questions.text: Which of the following disorders has an impaired thermoregulatory mechanism?
questions.solution:
Heat stroke is a severe heat disorder that occurs when the body's thermoregulatory mechanism fails. Sweating is absent in this condition. 

Heat stroke is likely to occur when the body temperature rises to 106-108 °F (normal 98.6 °F).

Heatstroke symptoms indicate a complete loss of thermoregulatory function. Common vital sign abnormalities include tachypnea, various tachycardias, hypotension, and a widened pulse pressure. 

The patients present with three main symptoms: hot, dry skin, dilated pupils, and a rectal temperature > 106°F. At these high temperatures, the body's temperature-regulating mechanisms often fail.

Heat stroke can occur in two forms:

  • Classic heat stroke (CHS) is seen in elderly individuals with chronic diseases who are predisposed to heat-related illnesses.
  • Exertional heat stroke (EHS) is seen in young, previously healthy people with prolonged exposure to or physical exertion in high temperatures. 

Heat stroke is a medical emergency, and the patient should receive treatment as soon as possible to decrease their temperature. The management involves actively cooling the patient by moving them to a cool place, applying a cold cloth, and giving them a cold water bath. Fluid replacement should also be done.

Other options: 

Option A: Heat syncope is caused by prolonged standing and working in a hot environment. The intact thermoregulatory mechanism causes vasodilation and venous pooling, which reduces blood flow to the heart and brain. This results in a syncopal attack and unconsciousness. Treatment involves recovery by lying down.

Option B: Heat cramps are a mild heat disorder caused by working in a hot environment. The intact thermoregulatory mechanism causes profuse sweating and loss of electrolytes, resulting in muscle pain and cramps. Treatment includes the replacement of electrolyte fluids.

Option D: Heat exhaustion/ heat collapse is due to excess vasodilation due to intact thermoregulatory mechanism which leads to reduced diastolic filling of the heart. The patient presents with dilated pupils and loss of consciousness. Treatment involves making the patient lie down and replacing fluids.

questions.text: The microscopic appearance of a tumour resected has a rosette-like arrangement as shown below. Identify the condition in which this feature is seen.
questions.solution:
The given rosette-like arrangement is called Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes and the condition in which this feature is seen is Retinoblastoma.

Rosettes are round assemblages of cells found in tumours. They usually consist of a halo or spoke-wheel arrangement of cells surrounding a central core or lumen.

Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes are seen in retinoblastomas. It has a well-defined true lumen surrounded by columnar cells.

Other options:

Option A, B and C: Medulloblastoma, Ewing sarcoma and Neuroblastoma have Homer-Wright pseudo-rosettes in histology. They do not have a lumen and have an eosinophilic centre.

Rosette type Morphology Tumour
Homer-Wright Central lumen or hub filled with fiber-like processes Medulloblastomas, PNET
Ependymal Empty-appearing lumen resembling a tubule Most well-differentiated ependymomas
Pseudorosette Spoke-wheel arrangement of cells with tapered cellular processes around a centrally placed vessel.  More sensitive for the diagnosis of ependymomas than true ependymal rosettes
Flexer-Wintersteiner Central lumen contains small cytoplasmic extensions of the encircling cells Retinoblastomas
Pineocytomatous Similar to the Homer Wright rosette, larger and more irregular in contour Pineocytomas 
Neurocytic Similar to the Homer Wright rosette, larger and more irregular in contour Central neurocytomas

Related Pearl: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

  • Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas
  • Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 
  • Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions
  • Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 

 

Medulloblastoma:

  • Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells
  • Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped
  • Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil

 

Ependymoma:

  • Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 
  • Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel

 

Oligodendroglioma:

  • Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 
  • Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries

 

Retinoblastoma: 

  • Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen
  • Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center
  • Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an etiological factor for head and neck malignancies?
questions.solution:
Vitamin A deficiency is not a risk factor for head and neck malignancies. Vitamin A deficiency is a risk factor for esophageal cancer.

The head and neck cancers include cancers of the oral cavity, pharynx, larynx, paranasal sinuses, nasal cavity, and salivary glands. Squamous cell cancer is the most common head and neck malignancy, often linked to tobacco and alcohol use. Non-squamous malignancies include thyroid cancer, salivary gland cancer, and sarcomas.

The risk factors for head and neck malignancies are listed below:

Oral cavity cancer: 

  • Tobacco, smokeless tobacco like Bidi, Chutta, Paan (oral tobacco mixed with betel leaf, areca nut, and salted lime), Khaini, and marijuana
  • Alcohol, poor oral hygiene, and intake of red meat and salted meat
  • Infections with human papillomavirus, and HIV 
  • Genetic conditions like  Li-Fraumeni, ataxia telangiectasia, Bloom syndrome, and Fanconi's anemia.

Oropharyngeal cancer: 

  • Smoking and alcohol
  • HPV 16 and 18

Cancer of the larynx and hypopharynx: 

  • Tobacco and alcohol
  • Nickel, mustard gas, and asbestos exposure
  • Long-term exposure to sulphuric acid and hydrochloric acid in battery plant workers.
  • Postcricoid carcinoma is associated with previous radiation and sideropenic dysphagia
  • HPV infection and immunosuppression

Nasopharyngeal cancer: 

  • Chinese population
  • Epstein Barr virus infection
  • Nitrosamines in salted fish and meat
  • Vitamin C deficiency

Cancers of the nasal cavity and paranasal sinus: 

  • Tobacco
  • Occupational exposure to dust from wood, textiles, and leather. Nickel and chromium dust and mustard gas exposure. 
  • HPV 16 and 18

Thyroid cancer: 

  • Females
  • Previous radiation
  • Inherited conditions like Gardner syndrome, familial polyposis, and Cowden syndrome. Medullary thyroid cancer associated with MEN-2 syndrome

Salivary gland carcinoma: 

  • Previous radiation

  • Smoking and heavy alcohol consumption were linked to a higher risk of salivary gland cancer in men but not in women

questions.text: The following image represents the number of cases of iron-deficiency anemia detected in an old-age home between January 1 to December 31. How many cases would you include to calculate the period prevalence of iron-deficiency in the year?
questions.solution:
The period prevalence in this scenario includes all the cases i.e., new, old and current, that existed at any time between January 1 to December 31, represented by all the straight lines present in the given date range which are A, B, C, D, E, G, and H,  a total of 7 cases.

Other options:

Option A: 3 could be the incidence in the previous year, i.e., the number of new cases before January 1.

Option B: 4 could be the incidence in the current year, i.e., the number of new cases after January 1 and before December 31.

Option D: 8 is the total number of cases, which could be the period prevelence if the time range includes the previous, current, and following years.

Related Pearl: Incidence and Prevalence

Incidence in Epidemiology:

  • Incidence is the number of new cases occurring in a defined population during a period of time.
  • Incidence = (Number of cases of a disease in a specified period of time/Population at risk during that time) x 1000
  • Incidence rate is expressed in person-time units, usually per 1000 per year.
  • It provides insight into the effectives of health services and programs.
  • Incidence rate of spells of sickness =  (Number of spells of sickness starting in the specified period/Mean number of people exposed to that risk in the specified time) x 1000
  • It is generally used for acute illnesses.
  • Special types of incidence rates:
    • Attack rate: It is used when there is a risk for a limited period of time.
    • Secondary attack rate: It is the number of exposed persons developing the disease within the range of incubation period following exposure to a primary case.
  • Incidence can be determined from cohort studies and longitudinal studies.

Prevalence in Epidemiology:

  • Prevalence is the proportion of all cases, old and new, of a particular disease at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population.
  • It is a proportion, not a rate or ratio.
  • It can be determined from cross-sectional studies.
  • Types:
    • Point prevalence is the prevalence at a point in time. Usually, prevalence is point prevalence unless otherwise specified.
    • Period prevalence is the prevalence over a period of time.
  • Prevalence is always expressed in percentage.
  • Prevalence = (Number of all cases of a specified disease at a given point in time/Estimated population at the same point in time) x 100
  • It is useful to determine the magnitude of health problems.

Relationship between Incidence and Prevalence:

  • Prevalence depends upon incidence and duration.
  • Prevalence = Incidence x Mean Duration
  • Longer the duration of the disease, greater the prevalence.
  • In acute diseases,because of rapid recovery/death prevalence will be relatively lower than incidence.This is because in some diseases (eg. food poisoning), the disease is so short lived, there are no "old cases".
  • In chronic diseases like TB, prevalence will be higher than incidence.
  • If a new treatment for a disease is effective, incidence does not change but prevalence decreases as duration of disease decreases.
  • If treatment only prevents death but doesn’t cure the disease, it may cause a paradoxical increase in prevalence.

questions.text: A patient underwent cystoscopy, which showed multiple yellow-white plaques in the trigone of the bladder. The histopathology image is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The cystoscopy findings of multiple yellow-white plaques in the trigone of the bladder and histopathology image showing Michaelis–Gutmann bodies are consistent with the diagnosis of malakoplakia.

Malakoplakia is a rare inflammatory reaction seen in chronic cystitis. It is caused due to acquired defects in phagocyte function, chronic bacterial infection by Escherichia coli or Proteus species, and immunosuppression (renal transplant patients).

The term malakoplakia means soft plaques. Grossly, malakoplakia appears as soft, yellow, slightly raised mucosal plaques. 

Microscopically, they are composed of large, foamy macrophages mixed with occasional multinucleate giant cells and lymphocytes. The macrophages in malakoplakia have abundant granular cytoplasm due to phagosomes stuffed with undigested bacterial products and intracellular deposition of calcium and iron within enlarged lysosomes form laminated basophilic concretions. These are known as Michaelis–Gutmann bodies, pathognomonic of malakoplakia (shown below).

 

The image given below shows the Von Kossa stain demonstrating calcium and iron-containing Michaelis-Gutman bodies (MG bodies) in malakoplakia.

 

Note: Xanthogranulomatous cystitis is morphologically and probably pathogenetically similar to malakoplakia, but it lacks Michaelis–Gutmann bodies.

Other options:

Option A: Interstitial cystitis, also known as chronic pelvic pain syndrome, is a disorder of the urinary bladder that presents with urinary tract symptoms of more than six weeks duration of unknown etiology. Grossly, it is associated with chronic mucosal ulcers called Hunner's ulcers. Microscopically, there is a non-specific increase in mast cells in the submucosa. Biopsy should be done in all cases to rule out carcinoma in situ.

The cystoscopy image shows Hunner's ulcer, seen in interstitial cystitis.

 

Option C: Polypoid cystitis is an inflammatory lesion resulting from irritation of the bladder mucosa, most commonly due to indwelling catheters. The urothelium is thrown into broad bulbous polypoid projections due to marked submucosal edema. They must be differentiated from papillary urothelial carcinoma.

The given image below shows polypoid cystitis showing broad polypoid growth, prominent blood vessels, and metaplastic urothelium in H&E stain.

 

Option D: Acute cystitis is characterized by an inflammation of the urinary bladder following infection, most commonly by Escherichia coli, Proteus, Klebsiella, and Enterobacter. It is more commonly seen in women due to the short urethra. Microscopically, there is hyperemia and neutrophilic infiltration of the mucosa.

questions.text: In the given nerve action potential curve, which point represents the return of  Na+ channels to the closed state?
questions.solution:
At point C, Na+ channels close and K+ channels open, causing repolarization due to K+ efflux. 

The sequence of events occurring during a nerve action potential is as shown below:

 

Point A - Resting potential. A state where both Na+ and K+ channels are closed. 

Point B - Threshold potential. Na+ channels open in response to depolarizing stimulus and Na+ influx occurs. The initiation of action potential occurs only after a certain potential is reached, called the threshold potential.

Point C - Peak of action potential. The sodium influx causes the opening of more Na+ channels through a positive feedback loop. Rapid depolarization occurs. At point C, Na+ channels close and K+ channels open, causing repolarization due to K+ efflux. 

Point D - Repolarization and hyperpolarization due to continued  K+ efflux.

Point E - After Hyperpolarization. The K+ channels slowly return to the closed state, causing after-hyperpolarization. Na+ channels are reset and are ready to respond to another depolarizing stimulus.

Both channels then close and the membrane returns to resting membrane potential.

questions.text: Which of the following units of population is considered for calculating the under-5 mortality rate?
questions.solution:
The under-5 mortality rate is calculated as a rate per 1000 live births.

The under-5 mortality rate is defined as the annual number of deaths of children under 5 years of age, expressed as a rate per 1000 live births. It is considered the best single indicator of social development and well-being. 

Recent analysis indicates that children from economically disadvantaged households face a two-fold higher likelihood of mortality before reaching the age of 5 years compared to their counterparts in wealthier households. Thus, the under-5 mortality rate also indirectly reflects the economic status of a country.

The primary causes of death among children under 5 encompass pneumonia, complications from preterm birth, intrapartum complications, neonatal sepsis, diarrhea, malaria, and injuries. The Integrated Management of Childhood Illnesses (IMCI) strategy is designed to tackle these fundamental contributors to childhood mortality.

questions.text: An asthmatic patient presents with bilateral nasal stuffiness. On rhinoscopy, multiple grape-like masses were seen. Identify the incorrect statement about this condition.

The given clinical scenario of an asthmatic patient presenting with bilateral nasal stuffiness and rhinoscopy showing multiple grape-like masses is suggestive of ethmoidal polyps. They are insensitive to probing and do not bleed on touch. Hence, option D is incorrect.

  • Asthma
  • Aspirin intolerance

questions.text: The years of potential life lost could be attributed to______.

choices.text: Years lost due to premature death
Years lost to poor quality of life

questions.solution:
The years of potential life lost could be attributed to the years lost due to premature death.

It is a mortality indicator that shows the number of years that a dying person could have expected to survive (usually taken as 75 years). Mortality indicators are used as the starting point in the evaluation of health status. They are used as indirect indicators of health.

The concept of years of potential life lost (YPLL) is used to estimate the societal impact of premature death. It helps prioritize public health interventions and allocate resources to address significant health problems. YPLL, along with other metrics like DALYs and QALYs, aids in assessing the burden of disease and the effectiveness of healthcare interventions. These measurements can help inform policymakers and healthcare providers in making informed decisions about healthcare delivery and resource allocation.

Strategies to reduce YPLL include prevention and early intervention, improving access to healthcare, and addressing social determinants of health that contribute to health disparities and premature death.

Other options:

Option A: Years lost to morbidity refers to the time spent living with a disease or disability, which is not directly related to the concept of years of potential life lost.

Option C: Years lost to disability is a component of disability-adjusted life years (DALY). DALY indicates the number of years lost due to ill health, disability, or early death. 

DALY = YLL +YLD 

  • Years lost to disability (YLD): Here, the number of cases due to injury and illness is multiplied by the average duration of the disease and a weighting factor. (Severity of the disease on a scale of 0 (perfect health) to 1 (dead))
  • Years of lost life (YLL) - Here, the number of deaths at each age is multiplied by the expected remaining years of life. (according to a global standard of life expectancy)

Option D: Quality-adjusted life year (QALY) indicates how the health status of an individual impacts his quality and quantity of life. It shows the years of life lost due to injury or illness. It is commonly used in evaluating the outcomes of medical interventions.

Colour blindness is the inability to appreciate one or more of the 3 primary colours, i.e. red, green, and blue. It can be congenital or acquired. Hereditary conditions can be classified into dyschromatopsia (colour confusion) and achromatopsia (rod monochromatism).

  • Holmgren's wool-matching test
  • Naegels anamoloscope
  • Farnsworth Munsell 100 hue test

Option B: Farnsworth–Munsell 100-hue test is a spectroscopic test (the patient arranges colour chips in ascending order) and consists of 85 caps of different hues in four racks. The colour vision is judged according to the error score, such that a greater error score means poorer colour vision. It is the most sensitive test for both congenital and acquired colour vision defects.

Option D: City University colour vision is a spectroscopic test where a central coloured plate should be matched with the closest hue from the four surrounding colours present in 10 plates.

The correlation coefficient (denoted by r) is represented by a plus or minus sign, followed by a number (Example: -0.88). The correlation coefficient ranges from -1 to +1.

The numerical indicates the strength of correlation:

  • Correlation coefficients greater than ± 0.5 are considered strong and are likely to establish (if positive correlation) or disprove (if negative correlation) the association between two factors.
  • Correlation coefficients between 0 and ± 0.5 are regarded as weak.

The sign indicates the direction of the correlation.

  • Plus sign (+) suggests that both the variables being studied are positively correlated. This means that the high value of one variable is associated with a high value in another. An example is an association between salt intake and blood pressure readings.
  • Minus sign (-) suggests that both the variables being studied are negatively correlated. A high value of one variable such as cigarette consumption is associated with a low value of another variable such as life expectancy.

The relationship between two correlated variables can be represented graphically in the form of a scattergram. Each point represents one observation including both the variables and so would be equal to the sample size. 

Related Pearl: Correlation

Correlation expresses the strength and direction of the relationship between two variables in terms of a correlation coefficient, signified by r.

Values of r vary from -1 (perfect negative correlation) to +1 (perfect positive correlation). Coefficients between ±0.5 and 1 are regarded as strong whereas those between ±0.5 and 0 are regarded as weak. The strength of the relationship is indicated by the size of the coefficient, while its direction is indicated by the sign. The data is plotted in a scattergram as shown in the examples given below.

Examples:

Positive Correlation (+r): High salt intake is associated with high blood pressure.

Negative Correlation (-r): Increase in smoking of tobacco is associated with a decrease in life expectancy. 

No correlation (r=0): Height of a person and his blood group.

Types of correlation coefficients

  1. Pearson product-moment correlation
    It is used for data that have continuous intervals like salt intake vs BP to find a linear relationship.
  2. Spearman rank-order correlation
    It is used for data that have discrete ordered intervals like socioeconomic status vs parity to find a linear or non-linear relationship.

Coefficient of Determination (CD) =  r2

It is simply the percentage variability in one factor due to change in another variable. For example - If a study finds a correlation (r) of 0.60 between smoking and life expectancy, it could be concluded that (0.6)2 = 0.36, or 36% of the variation in life expectancy in this study is accounted for by smoking.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl is found to have a power of -1.5 D spherical and -1.0 D cylindrical at 90 degrees. What is the type of astigmatism?
questions.solution:
The girl with a power of -1.5 D spherical and -1.0 D cylindrical at 90 degrees has against the rule astigmatism, as the horizontal meridian is greater and more curved than the vertical meridian.

Step 1: -1.5 D spherical indicates power of -1.5 on vertical and horizontal axes.
Step 2: -1.0 D cylindrical at 90 degrees indicates a power of -1.0 D at 180 degrees (perpendicular to 90). 

Hence, as the horizontal meridian (-2.5D) is greater than the vertical meridian (-1.5D), this would be against the rule astigmatism.

Astigmatism refers to the condition where there is different refractory power in both the principal meridians of the eye. Astigmatism is classified into two broad varieties - regular and irregular astigmatism.

Regular astigmatism: there are two principal meridians.
- With the rule (Option B) -  principal meridians are vertical and horizontal; both meridians at 90°; and the vertical meridian is more curved than horizontal.
- Against the rule -  principal meridians are vertical and horizontal; both meridians at 90°; and the horizontal meridian is more curved than vertical.
- Oblique - the principal meridians are not vertical and horizontal, but they are at 90° to each other; e.g., at 45° and 135°.
- Bi-oblique -  the two principal meridians are not vertical and horizontal, and they are not at 90° each other; e.g., at 40° and 100°.

Irregular astigmatism: there are multiple meridians.

Other options: 

Option A: In simple astigmatism, one of the meridia focuses on the retina. The other meridian focuses either in front of the retina (simple myopic) or behind the retina (simple hyperopic). Example, -1.00 DC × 180 degree.

Option C: Mixed astigmatism: Light rays in one meridian are focused in front of the retina and those in the other meridian are focused behind the retina. Example, -1DS with +2DC at 180 degree.

questions.text: Which of the following ion is responsible for the depolarisation of hair cells in the cochlea?
questions.solution:
K+ ion is responsible for depolarising hair cells in the cochlea.

The hair cells are located in the following six patches and correspond to the respective signals.

  • Organ of Corti - hearing
  • Utricle - horizontal acceleration
  • Saccule - vertical acceleration
  • Three semicircular canals - rotational acceleration.

The hair cell has a resting potential of -60 mV. When all the stereocilia bend towards kinocilium there is an influx of k+ resulting in depolarization. Depolarization in turn opens voltage-gated calcium channels in the hair cell membrane, and the resultant Ca2+ influx causes transmitter release from the basal end of the cell onto the auditory nerve endings. If the movement of the stereocilia is in the opposite direction, it leads to hyperpolarisation.

questions.text: Zellweger syndrome is due to defect in the biogenesis of _________________.
questions.solution:
Zellweger syndrome is due to a defect in the biogenesis of peroxisomes.

Zellweger syndrome is also known as cerebrohepatorenal syndrome. It is caused by mutations in the PEX family of genes. This results in defective beta-oxidation of very long-chain fatty acids, defective alpha oxidation, and impaired synthesis of bile acids and plasmalogens.

The child presents with

  • Dysmorphic facial features. 
  • Weakness, hypotonia.
  • Neonatal seizures
  • Eye abnormalities.

Biochemical findings will show :

  • Accumulation of very-long-chain fatty acids, phytanic acid
  • Abnormalities in the synthesis of bile acids
  • Marked reduction of plasmalogens

There is no appropriate treatment for Zellweger syndrome. It is very severe and infants rarely survive beyond a few months.

questions.text: Which of the following segments in the given image represents the 'incubation period'?
questions.solution:
In the given image, 3 represents the incubation period, which is defined as the time interval between the invasion by an infectious agent and the appearance of the first symptom or sign of the disease.

Other Options

Option A: 1 represents the latent period, which is the interval between the invasion by an infectious agent and the time from which the infected individual becomes infectious. 

Option B: 2 represents the infective period, which is the period from which the infected individual may transmit the organism to an uninfected individual. The infective period may begin before the appearance of the first clinical sign or symptom.

Option D: 4 represents the clinical period, which is the time during which an infected individual shows symptoms and signs of the disease.

questions.text:
Match the curves in the given graph with the changes occurring after death.
  1. Lividity
  2. Rigor
  3. Cooling
  4. Decomposition
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1-C, 2-B, 3-A, 4-D.

The graph with the changes occurring after death plotted against time is as follows:

Algor mortis/postmortem cooling is one of the early changes occurring after death. After death, the body loses heat mainly by conduction and convection. Up to the first hour, a temperature plateau may be seen due to the heat generated by residual metabolic activities of dying tissues. This is followed by a linear rate of cooling over the next 12 to 16 hours. The temperature rarely reaches the ambient temperature, most likely due to bacterial action with decomposition setting in. The curve is sigmoid or inverted S-shaped. 

Rigor mortis/cadaveric rigidity/death stiffening refers to the stiffening and shortening of muscles following death. It begins 1 to 2 hours after death and lasts for 24 to 48 hours in total. It starts disappearing after 12 hours.

Postmortem lividity/livor mortis develops in the dependent portions of the body due to engorged vessels showing through the skin. It develops shortly after death and may not be visible for up to 1 hour. It deepens in intensity between 1 to 4 hours and reaches a maximum by 6 to 12 hours. Lividity persists until putrefaction sets in.

Decomposition or putrefaction refers to the disintegration of the body tissues after death. Multiplication of the bacteria begins within 4 hours after death and by 18 to 36 hours gases collect in the body causing bloating and distortion. The body then undergoes putrefaction and liquefaction of the tissues 5 to 10 days after death.
