questions.text: An exclusively breastfed newborn was brought with vomiting and diarrhea that developed since birth. On examination, the baby is jaundiced and has hepatomegaly. Blood glucose level was low and erythrocyte galactose-1-phosphate level was elevated. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of an exclusively breastfed infant with vomiting, diarrhea, jaundice, hypotonia, and hepatomegaly with elevated erythrocyte galactose-1-phosphate level is suggestive of classical galactosemia.

Classical galactosemia is an autosomal recessive disorder. The enzyme deficient here is galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase (GALT). Normally, newborns receive up to 40% of their calorie intake as lactose (glucose + galactose). Without GALT, the infant cannot metabolize galactose 1-phosphate, which accumulates and causes injury to the kidney, liver, and brain.

Clinical features include vomiting, hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, jaundice, congenital cataracts, aminoaciduria, and failure to thrive. There is an increased incidence of Escherichia coli neonatal sepsis. Long-term complications include speech delays, learning impairment, motor dysfunction, and hypogonadotropic hypogonadism (in females).

The presence of galactose in urine (positive Benedict's test), elevated blood galactose level, and elevated erythrocyte galactose-1-phosphate level help in confirming the diagnosis.

Treatment is a galactose-free diet. Supportive therapy and the prevention of complications are important.

Other options:

Option A: Fructosuria is due to the deficiency of fructokinase. There are no symptoms except for the benign excretion of fructose in urine.

Option B: von Gierke's disease is due to glucose-6-phosphatase or translocase deficiency. It is a glycogen storage disorder (Type I).  They may develop hypoglycemia and lactic acidosis in the neonatal period, but hepatomegaly usually develops at 3–4 months. They may have doll-like facies, short stature, and a protuberant abdomen. Hyperuricemia, the elevation of triglycerides, low-density lipoproteins, and phospholipids are seen.

Option D: Hereditary fructose intolerance is due to a deficiency of fructose 1, 6-bisphosphate aldolase (aldolase B). Patients are healthy and symptom-free until fructose or sucrose is ingested. Clinical manifestations may include jaundice, hepatomegaly, vomiting, lethargy, irritability, and convulsions. It will not be seen in newborns who are exclusively on breast milk.

questions.text: Which of the following has the lowest oxygen concentration in fetal circulation?
questions.solution:
Among the fetal blood vessels mentioned above, the superior vena cava (SVC) has the lowest oxygen concentration. It carries deoxygenated blood from the upper part of the body to the right atrium.

The pO2 of SVC is about 12-14 mmHg whereas the pO2 of the umbilical artery is about 20-25 mm Hg. This is because the SVC carries only deoxygenated blood, whereas the umbilical artery carries a mix of oxygenated blood from the ascending aorta and deoxygenated blood from systemic circulation.

Fetal circulation:

The blood gets oxygenated in the placenta and this passes to the umbilical vein. From the umbilical vein, 50% of the blood enters the hepatic circulation and 50% bypasses the liver to enter the inferior vena cava. Thus, the inferior vena cava, which also carries blood from hepatic veins, kidneys, and from lower extremities, carries a mixture of deoxygenated and oxygenated blood. So, the highest percentage of oxygen in fetal circulation is in the umbilical vein, followed by the inferior vena cava. 

The blood then enters the heart via the right atrium. The right atrium also receives purely deoxygenated blood from the superior vena cava. This blood then enters the pulmonary artery. Since fetal lungs are collapsed, most of the blood enters the descending aorta via ductus arteriosus and is then distributed to the body. 

Finally, some of this blood from the aorta and the lower parts of the body is pumped back to the placenta via umbilical arteries. Hence, they contain a mix of both oxygenated and deoxygenated blood. 

The rough estimate of oxygenation of the vessels in the fetal circulation is given below:

Related Pearl: Concepts of Fetal Circulation

Concept 1:

Oxygenated blood from placenta to the fetus via the left umbilical vein.

Concept 2:

Most of the umbilical venous blood shunts via the ductus venosus to the inferior vena cava and gets mixed with deoxygenated blood from the lower part of the body and liver.

Concept 3:

One-third of blood from the inferior vena cava is directly pumped to the left atrium across the foramen ovale; then to the left ventricle; and ejected from there into the ascending aorta, where it supplies the upper body and the brain.

Concept 4:

A major portion of blood enters the right ventricle, mixes with blood from the superior vena cava, and ejects into the pulmonary trunk.

Concept 5:

Ductus arteriosus bypasses the lungs, and hence, a major portion pumps into the descending aorta to perfuse the lower part of the body and the umbilical arteries carry blood to the placenta for oxygenation.

The total fetal cardiac output at term is approximately 450 mL/kg/min.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented with fever, chills, and tender inguinal lymphadenopathy. Smears prepared from the discharge of these swellings revealed bacteria with bipolar staining. Which stain was used to prepare these smears?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of fever, chills, tender inguinal lymphadenopathy, and a smear showing bipolar staining of bacteria is highly suggestive of bubonic plague caused by Yersinia pestis. The stain used for this organism is the Wayson stain containing methylene blue.

Plague is a zoonotic disease caused by Yersinia pestis. It is a gram-negative, non-motile, coccobacillus. The reservoirs of infection are wild rodents like field mice, gerbils, skunks, etc. In India, the gerbil (Tatera indica) is the main reservoir. The important vector of plague is rat flea (Xenopsylla cheopis).

Humans acquire the disease by the bite of an infected flea, by direct contact with the tissues of the infected animal, or by droplet infection from cases of pneumonic plague. 

Human plague mainly presents as:

Bubonic plague- This is the most common type of disease. The patient develops a sudden fever, chills, headache, and painful lymphadenitis. Within a few days, the lymph nodes in the groin, axilla, or neck enlarge and are called buboes. This is followed by the suppuration of the buboes. Bubonic plague cannot spread from person to person as the bacilli are locked up in the buboes and do not find a way or easy exit.

Pneumonic plague- It develops as a complication of bubonic-septicemic plague. 

Septicemic plague- It occurs when the infection spreads to the blood.

Laboratory diagnosis- Microscopy reveals bacteria that show characteristic bipolar staining or safety pin appearance when stained with Wayson's stain. Antibodies to the F1 antigen of the bacteria can also be demonstrated by passive hemagglutination. PCR is used for a rapid presumptive diagnosis.

Treatment- Streptomycin, doxycycline, and chloramphenicol can be used.

Other options:

Options B & D- Albert's and Neisser's stains are used to stain Corynebacterium diphtheriae. They show the bacteria with metachromatic granules arranged in chinese-letter or cuneiform pattern.

Option C- Warthin-starry stain is used to stain Bartonella henselae which causes cat-scratch disease.

Related Pearl: Rat Fleas

  • Rat fleas belong to the genus Xenopsylla.
  • Their morphology includes a conical head, no neck, a thorax that has 3 segments and an abdomen with 10 segments.  They have three pairs of legs and no wings.
  • The four stages in their life cycle are egg, larva, pupa and adult.
  • They cannot fly but can leap up to 6 inches horizontally.
  • They transmit diseases by biting, mechanical transmission and feces.
  • Flea indices that are used in flea surveys are general flea index, specific flea index, percentage incidence of flea species and rodent infestation rate.
  • Rat fleas are vectors for endemic typhus (murine typhus), chiggerosis, bubonic plague and hymenolepis diminuta.
  • Insecticidal control is mainly 10% DDT.
  • Resistance to DDT, gamma-HCH and dieldrin has been recorded.
  • Repellants like diethyltoluamide and benzyl benzoate are efficient.
  • Rodent control also aims to reduce flea infestation.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman with a menstrual abnormality is prescribed tranexamic acid. Which class does this drug belong to?
questions.solution:
Tranexamic acid is an antifibrinolytic agent. It is approved for treating heavy menstrual bleeding.  

It is a lysine analogue that binds to the active site of plasmin and prevents the interaction of fibrin with plasmin. This prevents the dissolution of clots (fibrinolysis) and decreases bleeding. It can also be used to reverse excessive fibrinolysis.

Other options:

Option A: Drugs that stimulate the conversion of plasminogen to plasmin for fibrin metabolism are called Fibrinolytics (option A). It consists of recombinant tissue plasminogen activator and its variants like urokinase and streptokinase.

Option C: Anticoagulants are drugs that inhibit the formation of clots, given to patients at risk of developing serious consequences due to clot formation. It can be done by inhibiting various levels of clot formation. It broadly includes agents that stimulate antithrombin activity, Vitamin K antagonists, thrombin inhibitors and Factor Xa inhibitors.

Option D: Drugs that inhibit platelet aggregation and platelet function in the formation of a clot are called antiplatelet drugs. These drugs can be classified as thromboxane inhibitors, agents that block adenosine uptake, P2y12 antagonists, and glycoprotein 2b/3a inhibitors.

questions.text: A rural woman presents with her neonate having the condition shown in the image below. The neonate was healthy for the first 2-3 days after birth following which he developed progressive difficulty in taking feeds. She had a normal delivery but had not received any antenatal care. The possible cause is:
questions.solution:
The given image shows a neonate with opisthotonus and progressive difficulty in taking feeds indicates lockjaw. The history indicates that the mother was not vaccinated during pregnancy. All these features are suggestive of neonatal tetanus.

Cerebral palsy is less likely as this condition does not show such rapid progression within days. Also, the lady had a normal delivery. CP is usually associated with hypoxia and injuries during birth, prematurity, and genetic abnormalities.

Neonatal meningitis and encephalitis may also lead to opisthotonus but do not correlate with progressive difficulty in taking feeds and unvaccinated status of the mother.

questions.text: The  fallopian tube is lined by ______.
questions.solution:
The lining epithelium of the fallopian tube is a single layer of ciliated columnar epithelium. 

The ciliated epithelial cells are predominant in the distal part of the fallopian tube. There is an increase in the height and number of cilia in these cells during the estrogenic phase of the menstrual cycle.

Other cells in the fallopian tube epithelium include:

  • Secretory or peg cells - maximally located in the proximal portion of the tube. These cells are active around the time of ovulation, and their secretions help in the capacitation of sperms.
  • Intraepithelial lymphocytes - may present occasionally. 

 

Related Pearl: Fallopian tube

Gross anatomy:

The fallopian tube is divided into the following parts:

  • Intramural/Interstitial portion:  
    • Intrauterine
    • The narrowest and shortest part
  • Isthmus:
    • The most common site for tubectomy
  • Ampulla:
    • The longest part
    • The most common site for - fertilization and ectopic pregnancy
  • Infundibulum:
    • The widest part

Histology:

The ampulla, isthmus and infundibulum are extrauterine. They're covered by three layers: 

  • Mesosalpinx - It is the peritoneal layer. Also called serosa.
  • Myosalpinx - It contains smooth muscle and has 2 layers:
    • Inner circular 
    • Outer longitudinal
  • Endosalpinx - It is the mucosal layer. It has the following features:
    • Numerous branching folds, filling the entire lumen
    • Basement membrane
    • Ciliated, columnar epithelium 
    • Peg cells - non-ciliated epithelium. They help in the capacitation of sperms.

questions.text: A young man who had fractured his left humerus previously now doesn’t feel pain on his left little finger. On examination, the following deformity is observed. Which of the nerves is most likely to have been involved?
questions.solution:
The deformity shown is cubitus valgus. This along with the patient’s history of previous humerus fracture followed by loss of sensation over the little finger points to the involvement of the ulnar nerve.

Cubitus valgus can occur as a late complication of nonunion of fracture of lateral condyle of the humerus. The cubitus valgus deformity leads to the stretching of the ulnar nerve resulting in classic neuropathic symptoms which is termed tardy ulnar nerve palsy. Paresthesia in the ulnar nerve distribution with atrophy of the intrinsic hand muscles can be seen. It can be treated with ulnar nerve transposition and cubitus valgus correction.

The ulnar nerve supplies the medial two lumbricals in the hand. The lumbricals have a combined action on metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joint flexion and interphalangeal (IP) joint extension (glass holding posture). In ulnar nerve injury, since the medial lumbricals are not functional, the forearm muscles are unopposed. Hence, there is hyperextension at MCP joints and flexion at IP joints. This causes claw hand deformity. There is also numbness of the medial one and a half fingers.

questions.text: Which of the following is the cellular receptor for the RNA virus shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The given image showing a bullet-shaped virus, with nonsegmented single-stranded RNA is characteristic of rabies viruses belonging to the family Rhabdoviridae. The cellular receptor for the rabies virus is the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor.

Rabies is a fatal infection of the central nervous system transmitted by the bite of a rabid animal. It is caused by rhabdoviruses. questions.text: Which of the following trace minerals is essential for glucose tolerance and insulin sensitivity?
questions.solution:
Chromium potentiates the action of insulin in patients with impaired glucose tolerance, presumably by increasing insulin receptor-mediated signalling.

Rich food sources of chromium include: yeast, meat, grain products

questions.text: A 27-year-old male patient is brought to the emergency department with dyspnea, fatigue, and altered mental status. Examination reveals a temperature of 101 F. Laboratory investigations show a platelet count of 60,000 cells/cu mm and creatinine levels of 2.5 mg/dl. Which of the following is not likely to be seen on the peripheral smear in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes the classical pentad of thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP). This condition is a cause of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, which is seen on the peripheral blood smear and spur cells are not likely to be seen in this case.

Triangle cells, burr cells, helmet cells, and red cell fragments (schistocytes) are seen in blood smears due to intravascular hemolysis following trauma to the red blood cells in microangiopathic hemolytic anaemia.

The other causes of microangiopathic hemolytic anaemia include:

  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) (Most common)
  • Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS)
  • Malignant hypertension
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Disseminated cancer

The common pathogenic feature in all these disorders is microvascular lesions due to the deposition of platelets causing luminal narrowing. This leads to shear stress that injures passing RBCs.

TTP is a thrombotic microangiopathy occurring due to a deficiency in the plasma enzyme ADAMTS13  also known as vWF metalloprotease. Normally, ADAMTS13 cleaves multimers of vWF but in its absence, the large multimers accumulate in plasma thereby causing platelet activation and aggregation spontaneously. This leads to clinical manifestations.

The manifestations are fever, thrombocytopenia, microangiopathic hemolytic anaemia, neurologic deficits, and renal failure.

Option A: Triangle cells are small red cell fragments of varying shapes with sharp angles or spines with a dark or pale centre.

Option B: Echinocytes or Burr cells are pathologic red cells that have short and regularly spaced spicules with preserved central pallor. It is seen in uremia, bleeding ulcers, and gastric carcinoma. The image below shows Echinocytes.

Option C: The following image shows helmet cells/schistocytes which are distorted and fragmented cells with two or three pointed ends. They are seen in microangiopathic hemolytic anaemia.

Option D: Acanthocytes or spur cells are red cells that have spicules at irregular intervals. The spicules are of varying lengths and dense centres. These are seen in liver disease, abetalipoproteinemia and post-splenectomy. The images of acanthocytes are shown below :

questions.text:
Arrange the following structures in order of aqueous flow :
  1. Episcleral vein
  2. Trabecular meshwork
  3. Aqueous vein
  4. Schlemm’s canal
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of structures through which aqueous flows is: Trabecular meshwork (2) → Schlemm’s canal (4) → Aqueous veins (3) → Episcleral veins (1).

Circulation of aqueous humor is necessary both for metabolic purposes and to regulate intraocular pressure. There are two pathways of aqueous outflow :

  • Trabecular/conventional outflow – Main outlet draining 90% of aqueous via trabeculae.
    • Greater part of the fluid is formed in the ciliary region, it flows from the posterior chamber through the pupil into the anterior chamber and escapes through the drainage channels at the angle, i.e. Trabecular meshwork → Schlemm’s canal→ Aqueous veins→Episcleral veins→ Superior ophthalmic vein→Cavernous sinus.
  • Uveoscleral outflow – Drains around 10% of aqueous via ciliary body into the suprachoroidal space, and is drained by the venous circulation in the ciliary body, choroid and sclera.

The rate of formation of aqueous humor is 2-3 μL/min. Formation of aqueous humor involves the following:

  • Ultrafiltration
  • Secretion- Na/K ATPase of non-pigmented epithelium of the ciliary process
  • Diffusion

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with nausea, vomiting, and irrational behaviour two days after swimming in a freshwater lake during a camping trip. He is diagnosed with rapidly progressing meningoencephalitis and, unfortunately, passes away soon after. What is the most likely cause of his illness?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette is strongly suggestive of primary amoebic meningoencephalitis (PAM) is most likely due to the organism Naegleria fowleri, a pathogenic free-living amoeba. 

It mostly affects previously healthy young adults or children. The infection sets in acutely following swimming or diving in ponds or other warm, freshwater bodies. The incubation period varies from 2 days to 2 weeks.

They are free-living amoeba and exist in three forms - cyst, ameboid trophozoite form, and flagellate trophozoite form.

The amoeba invades the nasal mucosa and passes through the olfactory nerve branches in the cribriform plate into the meninges and brain to initiate acute purulent meningitis and encephalitis or primary amoebic meningoencephalitis (PAM).

Clinically, patients present with anosmia during the incubation period. Following this, the disease advances rapidly, causing fever, headache, vomiting, neck stiffness, ataxia, seizures, and coma. It is fatal in the majority of cases and death usually occurs within one week.

Microscopic analysis of CSF will reveal motile amoeboid trophozoites.

Treatment is with intravenous amphotericin B, which is the drug of choice. 

Other options-

Option B: Acanthamoeba is also a free-living amoeba. These organisms may also cause granulomatous amebic encephalitis, an infection of the brain and spinal cord. It usually occurs in immunocompromised patients and the incubation period and course of illness are typically slow. These features are in contrast to this patient's acute presentation and rapid deterioration, thereby suggesting another diagnosis.

Option C: Cryptosporidium species are implicated in causing traveler's diarrhea in immunocompromised patients. 

Option D: Entamoeba Histolytica is intestinal amoebae that are transmitted fecally. They are implicated in amoebic colitis and amoebic liver abscesses.

questions.text: Which of the following laryngeal rehabilitation methods is depicted in the given image?
questions.solution:
The given image represents oesophageal speech

Vocal rehabilitation after total laryngectomy is broadly divided into:

  • Esophageal speech
  • Artificial larynx
  • Tracheo-oesophageal speech         

Oesophageal Speech-  the patient is taught to swallow air and hold it in the upper oesophagus and then slowly eject it from the oesophagus into the pharynx. The patient can speak 6-10 words before re-swallowing air. The voice is rough but loud and understandable.

Other options:

Options A & C: Electrolarynx and transoral pneumatic devices are methods of artificial larynx.

Option D: Tracheo-Oesophageal Speech- Here the air is diverted from the trachea to the oesophagus or hypopharynx by the creation of a skin-lined fistula or by the placement of a prosthesis. The vibrating column of air entering the pharynx is then modulated into speech. The prostheses used are Blom-Singer and Panje devices. They have inbuilt valves which work only in one direction thus preventing problems of aspiration.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the the cause of the given finding?
questions.solution:
The given finding is known as Lichtenberg's figures or filigree burns which are pathognomonic for lightning injury. It is a superficial, thin, tortuous, fern-like pattern of erythema in the skin. It indicates the path taken by the electrical discharge and tends to follow skin creases and long axis of the body.

They are also known as arborescent burns or feathering as they have a resemblance to the branches of a tree. Lichtenberg's figures occur due to the rupture of small vessels. They are usually seen over the shoulder or flank within an hour of injury and disappear in 1-2 days.

Medico-legal aspect: Its recognition may be lifesaving in the unaccompanied comatose patient and is important because even delayed resuscitation of lightning victims can be very successful.

Lesions seen in electrical burns or electrocution are:

  • Joule burns: When the skin has been in firm contact with an electrical conductor, this may split the layers of the epidermis or the epidermal-dermal junction and produce a raised blister, called Joule burns.
  • Spark lesion: When the contact is less firm, an air gap (albeit narrow) exists between skin and conductor, the current jumps the gap as a spark. This causes the outer skin keratin to melt over a small area. On cooling, the keratin fuses into a hard brownish nodule, usually raised above the surrounding surface, the so-called spark lesion. The heat generated by the current may melt the calcium phosphate, which is radiologically seen as typical round dense foci known as bone pearls or wax drippings. 
  • Crocodile skin effect is caused by high-tension current burns. In high-voltage burns, such as those sustained from high-tension grid transmission cables, where the voltage is in the multi-kilovolt range, sparking may occur over many centimeters. This can cause multiple spark lesions giving rise to a crocodile-skin effect.

The image given below shows Joule burns

 

The image given below shows high voltage burns due to electrocution causing multiple spark lesions. Inset shows crocodile skin effect

Image below shows electrical marks

Marbling is a postmortem finding seen when blood in the vessels is haemolysed to sulfmeth-hemoglobin, which stains the vessel walls and the adjacent tissues, giving rise to a marbled appearance.

questions.text: An infant seems normal at birth but develops breathing difficulties shortly after birth with feeding problems, vomiting, and hypotonia. His urine was found to have a characteristic smell of tomcat urine. Which of the following is used in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
Tomcat urine odor is seen in Multiple carboxylase deficiency. Affected infants should be treated with Biotin.

Multiple carboxylase deficiency refers to one of two inherited defects of biotin metabolism.

  • The neonatal/infantile form is caused by a deficiency of holocarboxylase synthetase and presents in the first week of life with lethargy, poor muscle tone, and vomiting.
  • Juvenile/late form is caused by biotinidase deficiency and is associated with a slow but progressive loss of biotin in the urine, leading to organic aciduria. It is characterized by alopecia, ataxia, ketoacidosis, dermatitis, seizures, myoclonus, and nystagmus.

Both infantile and late-onset multiple carboxylase deficiency can be treated with pharmacological doses of biotin.

It is called multiple carboxylase deficiency because biotin is a water-soluble vitamin that is a cofactor for all 4 carboxylase enzymes in humans:

  • Pyruvate carboxylase
  • Acetyl CoA carboxylase
  • Propionyl CoA carboxylase
  • 3-methylcrotonyl CoA carboxylase

  1. Superior lobar bronchus

questions.solution:

  • Pulmonary artery
  • Principal bronchus

The medial surface of the lung is connected to the heart and trachea by a group of structures that enter or leave the hilum. It is called the pulmonary root. It is anteriorly related to the phrenic nerve, pericardiacophrenic vessels, and anterior pulmonary plexus. The vagus nerve and posterior pulmonary plexus form the posterior relation and the pulmonary ligament the inferior relation. 

The superior vena cava and right atrium are seen in front of the right root and terminal part of the azygos vein superiorly.

The aortic arch is seen superiorly and descending thoracic aorta posteriorly of the left root. The hilar structures are vertically arranged as:

  • Pulmonary artery
  • Principal bronchus
  • Inferior pulmonary vein

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with progressively worsening pain, redness in the right eye for the last two days. She has a history of sarcoidosis. On examination, the right eye is inflamed around the cornea, the pupil is constricted, and reacts sluggishly to light. The iris appears muddy. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with progressively worsening eye pain and redness, constricted pupil reacting sluggishly to light, muddy iris, and a history of sarcoidosis is likely to have anterior uveitis. 

Sarcoidosis is a systemic inflammatory disorder characterized by the formation of non-caseating granulomas. Anterior uveitis is often a presenting symptom of sarcoidosis.

Anterior uveitis presents with blurred vision, pain, photophobia, circumcorneal conjunctival injection (around the limbus) with an aqueous flare and keratin precipitates. The pupil is constricted and reacts sluggishly to light. The clear pattern of the iris is lost and it appears muddy.

In a slit-lamp examination, the following signs may be observed in anterior uveitis:

• Corneal signs: Presence of keratic precipitates.
• Anterior chamber signs: Hypopyon, presence of aqueous cells and flare, and a deep, irregular anterior chamber caused by posterior synechiae.
• Iris signs: Loss of the normal iris pattern, changes in color (commonly referred to as a “muddy iris”), and posterior synechiae.
• Pupillary signs: A constricted and irregular pupil, ectropion of the uveal pigment, and occlusion of the pupil (occlusion pupillae).

Steroids and cycloplegics are the mainstay of management for uveitis. Systemic therapy include steroids, NSAIDS and immunosuppressants.

Other options:

Option A: Acute bacterial conjunctivitis presents with pain, irritation, photophobia with hyperemia (pink eye), and purulent exudate. There is a diffuse conjunctival injection which is less seen in the circum-corneal region (as opposed to anterior uveitis)

Option C: Endophthalmitis is the infection of the intra-ocular cavities which presents with severe pain, loss of vision, and lid edema. It is usually seen in post-operative cases of ocular trauma (exogenous) and patients hospitalized with severe bacterial, viral, or fungal infections (endogenous).

Option D: Acute primary angle-closure glaucoma presents with severe unilateral eye pain, associated with headache and loss of vision. The examination shows a red congested eye, corneal edema with a shallow anterior chamber, and a mid-dilated pupil.

questions.text: A young male patient undergoes a submucosal resection. One week later, he presents with bilateral nasal obstruction and pressure sensation over the nasal bridge. On examination, smooth, rounded swelling of the septum is seen bilaterally. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis is a septal hematoma. 

Septal hematoma occurs when there is an accumulation of blood beneath the periosteum or perichondrium of the nasal septum. The most common cause of hematoma is nasal surgery or trauma. However, it is also seen in individuals with bleeding disorders. 

Patients present with bilateral nasal obstruction, frontal headache, and pressure sensation over the bridge. 

Examination, as seen in this patient, will show bilateral smooth rounded swellings of the nasal septum. If palpated, the mass will be soft and fluctuant.

The following image shows the bilateral, smooth, rounded swellings of the nasal septum indicative of septal hematoma. 

Treatment of septal hematomas involves aspiration with a wide bore needle if small, and incision and drainage if large. The incision can be made parallel to the nasal floor. Removing a small piece of nasal mucosa will aid in drainage. After drainage, the nose has to be packed bilaterally to avoid reaccumulation. 

Other options: 

Option A - Septal abscess occurs usually when there is a secondary infection of a septal hematoma. It is characterized by fever, chills, and frontal headaches. 

Option C - Septal perforation can occur after nasal surgery. Features depend on the size of the perforation. Smaller perforations can present with whistling while the larger perforations will present with epistaxis and crust formation. An image of septal perforation is given below.

Option D - Septal deviation is characterized by chronic unilateral or bilateral nasal obstruction. There is usually an external deformity and associated sinusitis, epistaxis, and anosmia.

  • Treatment:
    • Aspiration of small hematomas
    • Incision and drainage of large hematomas followed by nasal packing
    • Systemic antibiotics to prevent abscess formation
  • Complications: Septal abscess, depression of dorsum, permanently thickened septum

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy comes with complaints of hoarseness of voice. Endoscopy shows multiple growths on his vocal cords which are all less than 1cm in diameter. How should he be managed?
questions.solution:
This child with multiple growths on his vocal cords most likely has juvenile laryngeal papillomatosis. These lesions in a pre-pubescent boy with no complications should be managed expectantly and closely followed up till the child reaches puberty.

Laryngeal papillomatosis or juvenile papillomatosis is the most common benign neoplasm of the larynx in children. It is caused by HPV 6 and 11. It involves supraglottic and glottic regions of the larynx. Adult-onset laryngeal papillomatosis involves the anterior part of the vocal cords.

It usually occurs between the ages 3–5 years, but less commonly can also occur in men aged between 30-50 years. Clinical features include hoarseness or aphonia and respiratory difficulty. The recurrence rate is high but they rarely transform to SCC.

Diagnosis is confirmed by direct laryngoscopy and biopsy. 

Usually, these lesions resolve by puberty. If they occur on the free edge of the vocal cord they can be susceptible to trauma and bleeds. But otherwise, patients are managed conservatively unless there is significant lifestyle impairment. Treatment consists of micro laryngoscopy, CO2 laser excision, and topical cidofovir.

questions.text: A male patient presents with complaints of a sudden loss of taste and hearing loss. He also says he is unable to close one eye and tears do not stop flowing. On examination, there are lesions In the ear as shown in the image given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of loss of taste, sudden hearing loss, inability to close one eye, and epiphora along with vesicular eruptions in the external auditory canal and tympanic membrane is suggestive of Ramsay Hunt syndrome (herpes zoster oticus).

Ramsay Hunt syndrome is caused by the reactivation of Herpes zoster in the geniculate ganglion. In most patients, there is an involvement of the trunk of the facial nerve, which results in severe facial palsy.

Clinically, the patients present with all symptoms of facial palsy along with vesicular rash in the external auditory canal and pinna. The involvement of chorda tympani results in a loss of taste. 

The illustration given below shows the clinical features seen in Ramsay Hunt syndrome.

It may also be associated with hearing loss and vertigo due to the involvement of the 8th cranial nerve. There may also be anesthesia of the face due to the involvement of the 5th cranial nerve.

The treatment of Ramsay Hunt syndrome involves antiviral medications like acyclovir or famciclovir, as well as corticosteroids like prednisone.

Other options:

Option A: Bell's palsy is an idiopathic, peripheral facial paralysis or paresis of acute onset due to a lower motor neuron lesion of the facial nerve.

The image given below shows the clinical features seen in Bell's palsy.

 

Option C: Moebius syndrome is a congenital unilateral/ bilateral lower motor neuron facial nerve paralysis with abducens palsy causing abnormal ocular abduction.

Option D: Melkersson-Rosenthal syndrome is an idiopathic disorder consisting of a triad of:

  1. Facial paralysis
  2. Swelling of lips
  3. Fissured tongue

The image shows pitting pedal edema in a hypertensive patient. Calcium channel blockers (CCBs) like amlodipine are most likely to be associated with peripheral edema.

The frequency of CCB- induced peripheral edema is both drug-specific (i.e more potent drugs like amlodipine will be associated with higher rates of developing edema) and dose-dependent (i.e incidence of edema increases with an increase in drug dosage and chronicity of its usage). It is more common among females.

CCB-induced peripheral edema occurs due to a disproportionate decrease in the arteriolar resistance than in the venous circulation, resulting in increased hydrostatic pressure in the precapillary circulation. This leads to a fluid shift into the interstitial compartment causing edema.

Treatment:

  • Dose reduction.
  • Interclass switching of CCB - switch to non-dihydropyridines like verapamil, and diltiazem.
  • Addition of a venodilator - ACE inhibitor, ARBs, Nitrates.
  • Others - compression stockings, avoiding prolonged upright position.
  • Definitive treatment would be discontinuation of the CCB and switching to another class of antihypertensives.

Other options:

Option A: Common side effects of ACE inhibitors like enalapril include hypotension, hyperkalemia, dry cough, rashes, urticaria, dysgeusia, gastrointestinal upset, headache, and dizziness.

Option B: Telmisartan, an angiotensin receptor blocker (ARBs), causes adverse effects such as hypotension, hyperkalemia, headache, gastrointestinal upset, and dizziness.

Option D: Adverse effects of thiazide diuretics like hydrochlorothiazide are hypokalemia, hyponatremia, hyperglycemia, hyperuricemia, hypercalcemia, rashes, headache, gastrointestinal upset, and dizziness.

questions.text:
Match the following opportunistic infections with their most common timing of occurrence post-transplant:
Timing post-transplant Infection
1. <1 month A. CMV
2. 1-6 months B. BK Virus
3. >6 months C. Oral candidiasis
questions.solution:
The correct match sequence is 1-C, 2-A, 3-B.

1.  <1 month C. Oral candidiasis
2. 1-6 months  A. CMV
3. > 6 months B. BK Virus

 

Post transplant infections: 

  • Peritransplant (<1 month after transplant) - Oral candidiasis - This fungal infection is common due to antibiotic use, weakened immune system, and altered oral flora during the immediate post-transplant period.
  • Early (1-6 months after transplant) - CMV - This virus can reactivate from a latent state in the recipient, causing significant disease in the early months due to high immunosuppression levels.
  • Late (>6 months after transplant) - BK Virus - This virus typically infects the urinary tract or kidneys in the late post-transplant period, usually after tapering of immunosuppression.

The most common opportunistic infections in renal transplant recipients are as follows:

Early infections(<1 month): The most commonly seen infections include oral candidiasis and infections due to herpes viruses.
In the acute phase(1-6 months): Pneumocystis and cyomegalovirus infections develop in the patient
In the chronic phase(>6 months): Polyoma(BK) virus, nocardia and aspergillus are most commonly associated.

questions.text: A diabetic patient is undergoing a routine fundoscopy. Which of the following is the earliest finding likely to be found that would suggest a diagnosis of non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR)?
questions.solution:
Microaneurysms are the earliest finding in non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR) and is also very likely to be found in patients with a milder form of disease.

Diabetic retinopathy is used to describe retinal changes seen in diabetic patients. It is classified into the following types:

  • Non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR).
  • Proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR).
  • Diabetic maculopathy.
  • Advanced diabetic eye disease.

Related Pearl: Early treatment diabetic retinopathy study (ETDRS) classification

Non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR):

  • Mild NPDR
    • At least one microaneurysm must be present
  • Moderate NPDR
    • Microaneurysms/intraretinal hemorrhage in 2 or 3 quadrants
    • Early mild intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA)
    • Hard exudates and cotton-wool spots may or may not be present
  • Severe NPDR - any one of the following (4-2-1 rule)
    • 4 quadrants of microaneurysms and extensive intraretinal hemorrhages
    • 2 quadrants of venous beading
    • 1 quadrant of IRMA changes
  • Very severe NPDR - any two of the following (4-2-1)
    • 4 quadrants of microaneurysms and extensive intraretinal hemorrhages
    • 2 quadrants of venous beading
    • 1 quadrant of IRMA changes

Proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR):

  • PDR without high-risk characteristics (Early PDR)
    • Early neovascularization at the optic disc (NVD) or neovascularization elsewhere (NVE)
  • PDR with high-risk characteristics as follows
    • NVD < 1/4 disc area with vitreous hemorrhage (VH) or preretinal hemorrhage (PRH)
    • NVD 1/4 to 1/3 of disc area with or without VH or PRH
    • NVE > 1/2 disc area with VH or PRH

Clinically significant macular edema: 1 of the following 3 criteria are present on slit-lamp examination with 90D lens

  • Thickening of the retina at or within 500 micron of the center of the fovea.
  • Hard exudates at or within 500 micron of the centre of fovea associated with adjacent retinal thickening.
  • Development of a zone of retinal thickening one disc diameter or larger in size. At least a part of this should be within one disc diameter of the foveal center.

Advanced diabetic eye disease:

  • Persistent vitreous hemorrhage
  • Tractional retinal detachment
  • Neovascular glaucoma

questions.text: A young girl presents to you with delayed puberty. On examination, you notice a characteristic finding, as shown in the picture below. Apart from this, she has a shield-shaped chest. Investigations revealed the presence of normal gonads and pulmonary valvular stenosis. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical diagnosis based on features of short, webbed neck; shield chest; normal gonads; and pulmonary valvular stenosis is Noonan syndrome.

Noonan syndrome follows an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance. It involves mutations of the components of the RAS mitogen-activated protein kinase pathway (RAS-MAPK) pathway. The most common of these mutations is that of PTPN11, which encodes a protein tyrosine phosphatase on chromosome 12. Although it shares many clinical features with Turner syndrome, Noonan syndrome affects both sexes with normal karyotype.

Clinical features:

  • Down-slanting palpebral fissure (antimongoloid slant)
  • Pectus carinatum
  • Hypertelorism
  • Cryptorchidism
  • Low levels of clotting factors 11 and 12
  • Leukemia (Juvenile chronic myelogenous leukemia)
  • Moderate mental retardation in 25%
  • Cardiac abnormality: Most common is pulmonary valve stenosis.
    • Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
    • Atrial septal defect
    • Coarctation of the aorta
  • Short stature, webbed neck, low set ears, cubitus valgus (similarities with Turner syndrome)
  • Ptosis, micrognathia, clinodactyly, delayed puberty.

questions.text: A young female patient from a rural area presented with severe pain in the lower abdomen and pelvic regions, and vaginal bleeding. Her last menstrual period was 2 months back and her urine pregnancy test appeared positive. The physician suspects a ruptured ectopic pregnancy. Blood is most likely to collect in :
questions.solution:
The physician can confirm the diagnosis by obtaining the blood from the rectouterine pouch, which is also called as the pouch of Douglas. This procedure is called culdocentesis.

The classic triad of symptoms in tubal pregnancy are

  • Severe lower abdominal pain
  • Amenorrhea- usually for 6-8 weeks before the appearance of the symptoms
  • Vaginal bleeding

If a ruptured ectopic pregnancy is suspected, then blood samples should be sent for hemoglobin estimation and blood grouping. Estimation of β-HCG can be used to confirm pregnancy. Once it is suspected, transvaginal sonography or laparoscopy can be performed to visualize the ruptured ectopic.

However, if imaging techniques are not available, then culdocentesis can be performed. An 18 gauge lumbar puncture needle with a syringe is inserted into the rectouterine pouch by puncturing the posterior fornix. If non-clotting blood is obtained from the pouch which has a hematocrit of more than 15%, it indicates the presence of ruptured ectopic pregnancy.

Peritoneum of the female pelvis

In females, the peritoneum covers the anterior and anterolateral surfaces of the rectum, uterus, and urinary bladder. Spaces found in the female pelvis are:

Pararectal fossae- Present on either side of the rectum. They are limited laterally by the peritoneum that covers the uterosacral ligaments. 

Paravesical fossae- Present on either side of the bladder. It is limited laterally by the peritoneum which covers the round ligament of the uterus.

Rectouterine pouch (pouch of Douglas)- The peritoneum which covers the anterior surface of the rectum is reflected anteriorly to cover the posterior surface of the posterior fornix of the vagina and the uterus, forming a rectouterine pouch.

Vesicouterine pouch- The peritoneum covering the fundus and body of the uterus, is reflected anteriorly to cover the posterosuperior surface of the bladder forming a vesicouterine pouch.

Ovarian fossa- is a shallow depression in the peritoneal lining of the lateral pelvic wall between the peritoneal ridges. It is formed by the obliterated umbilical arteries anteriorly, the ureter posteriorly, and the external iliac vessels above. It lies behind the lateral attachment of the broad ligament and contains the ovary in nulliparous females.

questions.text: An autopsy was performed on a person with a history of drowning; however, the report revealed that there was no water in his lungs, hence the case was labeled as dry drowning. What is the most likely cause of his death?
questions.solution:
In dry drowning death is due to sustained laryngeal spasm and subsequent airway closure. This occurs when there is sudden entry of water into the nasopharynx or larynx.

Type of drowning  Cause of death

Freshwater drowning

Dry drowning Laryngeal spasm
Immersion syndrome Vagal inhibition
Post immersion Syndrome / Secondary drowning

Dry drowning:

In this type of drowning, water does not enter the lungs, but death results from immediate sustained laryngeal spasm due to an inrush of water into the nasopharyngeal or larynx. Thick mucus, foam and froth may develop, producing a plug.

Immersion syndrome (Hydrocution/Submersion inhibition):

Death results from cardiac arrest due to vagal inhibition as a result of

  • Cold water stimulates the nerve endings of the surface of the body.
  • Water striking the epigastrium.
  • Cold water enters ear drums, nasal passages, pharynx and the larynx which cause stimulation of the nerve endings of the mucosa.

Secondary drowning/Post immersion-syndrome/Near drowning:

It refers to a submersion victim who is resuscitated and survives for 24 hours. The patient may or may not be conscious. These patients may develop hypoxemia resulting in brain damage, electrolyte disturbances, pulmonary edema, sepsis, myocardial anoxia, etc., Death may occur from half to several hours after resuscitation in about 10-20% of people. Those who survive suffer from serious neurological damage.

questions.text: A chronic smoker was on nicotine replacement therapy and clonidine tablets for smoking de-addiction. He stopped taking clonidine tablets and now presents with a headache. Which of the following drugs is best suited for the treatment of his condition?
questions.solution:
The mechanism that causes headaches in this patient, who stopped taking clonidine, is rebound hypertension. Amongst the given drugs, phentolamine is best suited for the control of hypertension due to clonidine withdrawal.

Phentolamine is a non-selective alpha antagonist that opposes the alpha receptor-mediated vasoconstriction of sympathomimetics. It is also used in:

  • Clonidine withdrawal
  • Short-term control of hypertension in pheochromocytoma
  • Limiting the duration of soft tissue anesthesia.

Clonidine is an alpha-2 receptor agonist and a centrally-acting antihypertensive agent. It treats high blood pressure by stimulating presynaptic α2 receptors in the vasomotor center in the brainstem. This binding has a sympatholytic effect, by suppressing the release of norepinephrine and other sympathomimetics.

Abrupt withdrawal after long-term therapy can result in rebound hypertension, restlessness, and sympathetic overactivity. Dry mouth and sedation are the major side effects of clonidine. It can also cause impotency and constipation. Phentolamine is used for the control of hypertension due to clonidine withdrawal.

Other options:

Option A: Phenoxybenzamine is also a non-selective alpha antagonist but has irreversible action. Side effects are postural hypotension, palpitation, nasal blockage, miosis, and inhibition of ejaculation. It is used primarily in pheochromocytoma, and occasionally in peripheral vascular disease.

Option B: Prazosin is a selective alpha-1 blocker. It is a potent antihyper­tensive but is not used as a first-line drug because fluid retention and tolerance gradually develop with monotherapy. Another major problem with prazosin is marked postural hypotension and syncope following the first dose (first dose effect).

Option D: Propranolol is a non-selective beta-blocker that decreases heart rate, force of contraction, and cardiac output. It reduces blood pressure on prolonged administration. It has mem­brane stabilizing (Na+ channel blocking) properties and is a potent local anesthetic. It also reduces the secretion of aqueous humor.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most cost-effective method of infection control?
questions.solution:
The most cost-effective method of infection control is hand hygiene.

Infection control refers to the policy and procedures implemented to control and minimize the spread of infections in hospitals and other healthcare settings. It decreases infection rates and the development of multidrug-resistant pathogens. 

The most significant precaution that is effective in preventing infection transmission is hand hygiene. This is achieved by washing hands with soap and water and/or by hand rubbing with alcohol or non-alcohol-based hand sanitizer. The most effective and least expensive way is by washing hands before and after any patient interaction.

Perform hand hygiene

  • When hands are visibly soiled.
  • After barehanded touching of instruments, equipment, materials, and other objects likely to be contaminated by blood, saliva, or respiratory secretions.
  • Before and after treating each patient.
  • Before putting on gloves and again immediately after removing gloves.

Use soap and water when hands are visibly soiled (e.g., blood, body fluids); otherwise, an alcohol-based hand rub may be used.

Public health measures and activities such as sanitation, infection control, immunization, and protection of food and water supplies are all basic to primary prevention.

questions.text: A post-op patient develops purulent discharge from the incision site. The culture report shows Staphylococcus aureus resistant to an antibiotic that binds to the terminal  D ala-D ala sequence. Which of the following antibiotics can be used to treat this infection?
questions.solution:
Daptomycin is the drug of choice for vancomycin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (VRSA).

Daptomycin acts by first binding to the cytoplasmic membrane and then forming complexes in a calcium-dependent manner. Complex formation causes a rapid loss of cellular potassium, possibly by pore formation, and membrane depolarization. This is followed by the arrest of DNA, RNA, and protein synthesis resulting in cell death.    

The given scenario is that of a skin infection secondary to VRSA. Vancomycin is the antibiotic that binds to the terminal D ala-D ala sequence of peptidoglycan units needed for bacterial cell wall synthesis.

Other options:

Option A: Ceftazidime is a third-generation cephalosporin that is ineffective in VRSA infections.

Option B: Gentamicin is an aminoglycoside which is ineffective in VRSA infections

Option C: As the culture reports already show resistance to vancomycin, this is not the answer. However, vancomycin is the drug of choice for methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA).

questions.text: Your friend is planning a trip to the mountains but is concerned because of her history of severe nausea and vomiting while traveling anywhere. Which of the following drugs would be the least effective in managing her condition?
questions.solution:
The friend has motion sickness and ondansetron is the least effective drug in managing her condition.

Ondansetron is a 5 HT3 receptor antagonist. It blocks impulses at the peripheral origin in GIT and does not suppress vomiting caused by motion sickness. It is most commonly indicated for the treatment of postoperative and chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting. 

Drugs used in the treatment of motion sickness are:

  • Anticholinergic agents (muscarinic receptor antagonists) such as scopolamine (hyoscine) and dicyclomine.
  • Antihistamines (H1 antagonists) are primarily used for treating motion sickness and postoperative emesis.  

Scopolamine transdermal patches should be given prophylactically as it is less effective once symptoms start. It is applied behind the ear at least 4-12 hours before an anticipated exposure to motion. Dry mouth and sedation are common side effects.

First-generation antihistamines such as promethazine, dimenhydrinate, chlorpheniramine, diphenhydramine, cyclizine, and meclizine are effective in controlling nausea and vomiting in motion sickness. Sedation is a common side effect of these drugs. Second-generation antihistamines like cetirizine and fexofenadine are ineffective in the treatment of motion sickness.

questions.text: A new complement inhibitor, CI-100, is being investigated for safety and efficacy in 300 patients with active vasculitis. The trial randomizes patients to receive either CI-100 or placebo. What phase is this trial currently in?
questions.solution:
The given scenario describes a randomized study to assess the safety and efficacy of the drug in 300 patients, which was conducted during phase 2 of the trial.

Phase 2 trials are designed to assess the efficacy and safety of a new drug in a larger group of patients (50 - 500). The primary goal of a phase 2 trial is to determine whether the new drug is effective in treating the target disease or condition.

Clinical trials are experimental studies involving humans that compare the therapeutic benefits of 2 or more treatment options, or of a particular treatment to a placebo. 

Other options:

Option A: Phase 1 where subjects (mostly about 10-100 healthy volunteers) are exposed to the lowest possible dose, increasing stepwise to achieve the effective dose. The emphasis is to work out the safety, tolerability, and to detect any potentially dangerous side effects.

Option C: Phase 3 involves a large number of patients (about 500-3000) being assigned randomly to either the treatment under investigation (e.g., drug CI-100 in the question) or to the present standard of care (e.g., steroids as the first-line treatment of vasculitis). The aim is to establish the value of the drug in relation to existing therapy. If it is better than existing modalities, indications are finalized and guidelines for therapeutic use are formulated.

Option D: Phase 4 involves postmarketing surveillance of patients after the treatment is approved. It is used to detect efficacy, rare or long-term adverse effects, and evaluate cost-effectiveness.
